column11: Review Text

column8: Not recommended for normal tourists, maybe for botanists
column11: We went to the park in April. It is not worth it in our opinion. It's kind of a forest, we haven't seen any animals (just monkeys). Birds are all we heard. In the lake at the entrance are fish and turtles. We discovered a kingfisher after all. Unfortunately, however, we must warn against leeches. Don't go to the park with sandals and bare feet. Even with sturdy shoes and socks, the beasts in the shoe bit me through the socks. With bare feet, these things really strike. You can barely recognize them, but they're nasty.

column8: A Peaceful Escape at Usawattakele - Kandy
column11: I had the pleasure of visiting Usawattakele during my trip to Kandy, and it was a serene escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. Nestled on the hills, this tranquil area offers panoramic views of Kandy’s lush landscape and is perfect for a peaceful walk or a moment of relaxation. The natural beauty of Usawattakele, combined with its peaceful surroundings, made it an ideal spot to unwind. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a quiet retreat .
SHAME ON YOU! SHAME! Good birding spot, but they have elephants chained with marked, sad stereotypical movements. Good place for birding, but they have chained elephants.

column8: A pleasant walk in the park
column11: A Pleasant walk in the forest albeit a damp one just after the rain. Lovely viewpoint but did not observe many animals. Good leg stretcher if you are short of time.

column8: Worth a visit, but beware of chained up elephants
column11: This place is great to walk and not overly strenuous, the map is very deceiving and it's actually smaller than it looks. Some caves to see with paintings. Great but small Kandy town view. Bike hire is 500 for 2hrs, however, they don't have bikes that are suitable for kids under 12. Toilet facilties available at both ends of the park. It takes maximum 2hrs to walk around the largest loop, but can be cut and you can walk directly to the town lookout and average information centre and back within 45mins. Only downside is that you my stumble across an elephant prison camp at Point C on the map where 2 male elephants are chained to the trees slightly below the walking track. This was very upsetting to see as they were very distressed shaking their heads continuously side to side. Entry fee is Rs 900 for adults and Rs450 for children under 12. Majority of the reserve has canopy cover from the sun, so sunscreen not essential.
Just a greenish experience and it has to be more developed as a a sanctuary wood. It is to be used to identify the Kandy   bio diversity.

column8: A Tranquil Escape heart of Kandy City; Hiking Through Udawatta Kele Sanctuary
column11: We had an amazing hike in Udawatta Kele Sanctuary, a protected forest reserve located in the heart of Kandy. This sanctuary serves as a haven for diverse flora and fauna. Visitors can explore the network of hiking trails that wind through the sanctuary's lush, verdant landscapes, offering opportunities to spot various bird species, butterflies, and other wildlife. Udawatta Kele Sanctuary not only provides a serene and rejuvenating escape from the city but also underscores the importance of conservation efforts in safeguarding Sri Lanka's rich ecological heritage within urban settings.

I don't usually write reviews. But I got so angry today, I decided to write. Don't waste time if you don't have enough and if you're not a nerd. Walked around and didn't see NI-KO-GO! Not at all. It's not so much money as time spent. I'd rather just walk around Kandy.

930LKR to enter and 500 to rent a bike if you wish. They are in good enough condition but don’t expect gears to work; are a nice way to avoid leeches though if that’s a concern and it’s wet. Very well maintained paths with the forest looking to be in good condition. Look out for troops of monkeys being attracted to the hanging fruits!
The only positive thing about this walk in the forest is that you came home with only one leech per person. The forest is beautiful but without more, really not a must of this beautiful city.
Good for brief visit to forest experience in kandy. Within 2 hours can cover the track. Less variety of trees. Less parking space. They must have sign boards for directions.

We had an amazing hike in Udawattekele. It is not a safari, we saw some monkeys and millions of butterflies. There is constant beautiful birdsong but we did not see any birds. It is simply a great jungle walk. Take a photo of the large map on your way in, check out the visitors centre, make sure you go to the lookout over Kandy, enjoy the fresh air, exercise and birdsong. Its very easy to get to, take water with you as it will be hot and humid.

We arrived at 3.30. There was a notice at the ticket office, saying that the adult ticket was Rs930 and the child ticket was Rs47. We were two adults and one child. At first, they charged us Rs3000. After our argument, they charged us Rs2500. Although the money was not much, this kind of random charging made us feel disgusting. And the attitude of the ticket seller was very cruel. This was the worst place in Sri Lanka.
If you like hiking, like jungle, don’t afraid of monkeys, dogs, birds or any animals. I suggest you. Calm, fresh air, wonderful sounds.

Udawattekele Sanctuary is truly a hidden treasure near Kandy, offering a delightful and affordable escape into nature. Nestled just 15 minutes away from the bustling city, this sanctuary is a cool and refreshing haven. The tranquility and fresh air make it a perfect retreat, providing a unique forest experience in the busy hill capital of the country. The entrance fee is surprisingly reasonable, making it accessible to all. The immense biodiversity of both plants and animals adds to the allure of this natural royal forest. Ensure to bring extra water, as the trek can be quite lengthy. We had the pleasure of meeting officers at the information center and a knowledgeable and friendly guide who added to the richness of our visit. The sanctuary is clean, making it an ideal spot for a peaceful walk amidst a variety of birds and, if you're lucky, a glimpse of the Barking deer (we could photograph one) Washroom facilities are to be improved. In summary, Udawattekele Sanctuary is a worthy visit, offering a unique natural experience at an affordable cost. Its proximity to Kandy and the efforts towards conservation make it a special spot, despite a few minor considerations. Don't miss the chance to explore this amazing forest gem right in the heart of Kandy.

Udawattekele very nice and not too expensive. A cool and refreshing place near Kandy. Enjoy the quietness and fresh air. I am not sure how old this forest is, but it seems to look close to natural forest type that may have existed in this region. Giant liana is impressive

I can see why some were not that keen on this place, maybe think of it as a nice stroll in the forest more than anything, was a nice peaceful walk, beware of the monkey's as one came right for me to steal my bag I think so they are very confident. Was a nice walk but we had gone to the Botanical gardens which was fabulous. Was amazing that this was right in the middle of Kandy though.
Overrated forest. Cant see creatures only monkeys and one snake. The map is bad and don't know where are you because the signs are in Tamil.
We went on a hike to this fascinating jungle. The calmness and the beauty of it is amazing. I have never been to such a jungle and we would definitely visit this place when we come back
You can get a cool forest experience in a busy city of kandy, which is considered as the hill capital of the country. Worthy to visit and the entrance is also very cheap.

The overall experience was amazing! We went on a guided tour and it was the right way to do it I think. The guide was very informative and happy to answer any questions. The immense amount of biodiversity of both plants and animals was awesome, and to see some workers in the forest conserving against invasive species was wholesome to see. We seen various species of lizards, birds, turtles, monkeys, snakes!! Highly recommend visiting if in Kandy or travelling Sri Lanka.
Udawattekele is well-known place in heart of Kandy city. You can have a peaceful walk with fresh air.

Quite afternoon walk. We went on an afternoon when we had nothing planned there was a nice view of Kandy and it was a peaceful walk. There’s not that much to see but is nice if you have some free time.

Amazing natural royal Forest in the middle of kandy. Flora everywhere but, many invasive devil’s ivy vines destroy the valuable canopy trees. Have some more water with you as the treck is quite Longer. Found some ancient caves with full of rubbish in it. Officials need to clean it for visitor’s observations. Met a nice person at information centre One Mr Kapila, nice guy with full of knowledge. Place is clean, good for a walk with lots of birds and glimpse of Barking deer if you are lucky enough....

We were not overly impressed having already been to places like Sinharaja rainforest for a hike and Udawawale national park for safari. It’s close to Kandy central and we stopped off during a day exploring on tuk tuk. The forest loop walk took us just over an hour. Whether or not this was due to timing/time of year we will never know but we really didn’t see much wildlife. We visited around 3pm so perhaps why. We heard some birds and perhaps some monkeys but saw none on our walk. The trees etc are beautiful as always in Sri Lanka but we didn’t feel that with the walk was warranting of the ‘foreigner price’ of 1750 rupees for me and my wife included. Also beware of many leeches on the walk. Would avoid wearing sandals like we did - silly from our side. It’s nice enough but there are better walks in nature in Sri Lanka which are better maintained.

Udawattakele / Royal Forest of Kandy is just 15 minutes drive from Kandy city and it is famous for avifauna. It opens at 8am and closes at 5pm. You have to buy a ticket to enter the forest and carrying plastic items are prohibited. There are three meditation centers situated within the forest but needs permission to enter. Udawattakele has shaded foot pathways. The information center is situated at other end of the forest. It is better to some leech repellents in a wet day.  There is a view point at Udawattakele where Kandy city is visible. Giant Liana is a common finding at this forest.
This is a bird paradise I would day. If you are a bird lover this is the place you should be. Calm and quite. Not that much crowded so birds can be in peacefully. Love this place a lot.

The paths to walk on hadn't been swept of leaves ever and the noise of crickets was hard to hear anything else. The  locals who hardly had to pay to get in were using the few benches available to sit down on and there was no souvenir shops or people to buy rolexes or sunglasses from.
Hete you can have a nice walk, if you want to spot a lot of animals you have to go early morning, in the afternoon you maybe see a dear or some birds and monkeys

The sanctuary is located only a short distance from the Kandy city. The guard at the gate makes sure no one takes in polythene, cigarettes and alcohol etc. You could indulge in the tranquil beauty of nature within the premises. Besides the chirping of numerous birds and sounds made by monkeys, you would not hear the hustle and bustle of the busy city. There are benches placed for the tourists to sit and rest up. There is also a view point of the city from the sanctuary. A must visit to a nature lover.

It only takes about 15 minutes to reach the gate entrance of Udawattakele from the Municipal junction in Kandy. You can find the place without a hassle. There are plenty of trails that you can take once you enter to the park which can be found on the map. The best time to visit the place is in the morning around 07.00 am. So that you may be able to witness more fauna than in the afternoon. If you are lucky, you may witness Endemic animals like toque macaque, jackal, porcupine and mouse deer. Obviously 460 species of plants, especially lianas, Shrubs, herbs and small plants are survived in the jungle. There are 03 Buddhist temples are situated in this sanctuary namely they are Forest Hermitage, Senanayakaramaya and Tapovanaya. This is a good place to do meditation as well. If you want to ease of your mind this would be an ideal place. If so, you must visit this reserve in the morning as it gets crowded in the afternoon. When I visited the place, I had a feeling that this could have used to film lord of the ring as well. I would have even listened to some elfish music whilst on trial, if I had the earphones with me. It is a must to visit the sanctuary, if you are in Kandy. All in all, it is our duty to safeguard this wonderful nature reserve. Please do not throw trash into the wilderness.
Price is to High 900 it should only Cost 100, mayby thats why, we have the Wood for ourselves. Lacks decent signs on the rute or a map to follow.

take a tuktuk to the entrance so as not to spend your energy on finding it, also its uphill quite a bit - price is steep (900) but worth 2-3 hours of walking in a jungle like environment on maintained paths with moderate inclines - coolest thing is the giant liana which has grown to cover 2 hectares in 200 years - birds are hard to see in midday hours but you are likely to spot a sri lankan deer and we also saw a himalayan paradise flycatcher

Royal Forest Park in Kandy (primary rainforest), AKA Udawattekele Sanctuary. The tourist info guy practically begged me not to go because of the leeches! I thought of the big (presumably slow) leeches in the awesome film Stand By Movie and thought 'I'll be fine'. As I was entering two tourists left, one with blood trickling down leg from leech wound - ok maybe the threat is real! But I thought, if I keep a lookout surely a big slow leech can’t get on me. What I didn’t know is these leeches are thin, fast and so agile! I was moving fast and yet - agh! One on my sock trying to burrow through! Then another on my other sock. I used my hotel keycard to get them off quick but both had drawn blood (only a drop). Then one was on my arm! How did it get there?! Luckily I got this one off before it got me. I turned round and sprinted back for the main path. Sticking to the bigger path, that can take vehicles, was fine - this is a short (maybe 40 minutes) route including views over Kandy (where lots of monkeys were). The longer route of several kms is where the leeches were. I don’t know if it’s the same all year round, but probably best not to go when wet at least.

After spending a few hours walking around the city, the peacefulness of the forest was truly welcomed! We didn't seen much wildlife we saw only 1 deer on a 2 hour walk - but that didnt bother us; the forest is rich with biodiversity and the sound of wildlife. I found the forest to be well maintained - do bear in mind though that it is a forest so some paths may be a little less kept - but isn't that the point, it's a forest, not a maintained garden. Oh... definitely, definitely wear insect repellant, I was attacked by leeches...maybe my leech dance scared the animals off! Overall, even with a few cling on insects, I'm eally pleased that we went.
Beautiful part of Kandy, nice walk in quiet nature, not dfficult. But to pay 864 rupees for it? Come on....

You could almost forget that you were in the city, barring the occasional car horn intruding on the hum of cicadas. Don’t expect bright colours and lots of wildlife - although you may see both - expect an immersive hour or two in nature. Note that only the main entrance can be used - the path up from the Garrison cemetery is off-limits (although still sign-posted out from within the park). Easily walkable from central Kandy, but take a tuktuk if you must.

that is an amazing visit where you can have an idea of a Sri Lankan tropical rain forest, although the forest is not vast, you will enjoy it a lot , if it rains there are some leechers, prepare for that
A very calm quite and lush green place amidst bustling city. Take a stroll down to submerge into mother nature and talk to yourself. A quite time with you and nature.

We went in there and yes it is jungle in the city. Not well marked unless you know Sinhala. Saw a few skittish deer and hit a bunch of dead ends and come home with multiple cuts and bruises. It is quite pretty but I thought overrated and wasted our day.

We went to Udawattekele for a walk to escape the busy city setting of Kandy. It’s only a 10-15 min walk from the center of town, so we expected nothing more but a small forest. What we got though was a full jungle-experience with monkey, snake and barking-deer sightings. You can decide how much time you want to spend walking through as there are several loops, marked out on a big map by the entrance. Entrance fee 660 Rupees as of October 2019. Beware of the leeches. We got attacked a few times!
Good walk, plenty to see.  Our guide said it was about 3km to get around. Liar liar pants on fire, it was at 6 km's.  Plenty of monkeys all over the carpark and cars when we finished.

This sanctuary is pure beauty! It is so peaceful inside and a great escape from the bustling city. There are many different paths you can take in the park, some short for those not wanting to walk too far, and some longer ones for those after a longer walk. There is also a cycle path. There are also lots of monkeys, which are great entertainment! We also spotted a turtle in the river. This place is definitely underrated and should more a must see for anyone visiting Kandy!

Kandy can be pretty noisy. If your ears need a break, come here. Once we stepped into the forrest we felt like entering a different world - a very beautiful one. Make sure to take a map since the signs won’t always be a big help to you. Other than that just enjoy your time. We barely met other people and just enjoyed the hike and the beautiful viewpoint over Kandy.
amazing place to travel ,,,, just for calm down your mind..... there is a bicycle driving path also there

This is seriously a must do! We went up to the forest at 3.30pm and saw so many monkeys, it was the most amazing experience as we love seeing wild animals. Bring cash to pay the lovely old lady at the entrance and she will give you a map, can be done within an hour or two but recommend allowing more time so you can stop to take photos. We also saw 4 deer and some friendly stray dogs :) Highly recommend to all, such a beautiful, peaceful and quiet place. Tip: bring your own water bottles.

Did a really nice circuit around the park which offered a great viewpoint of Kandy. However there were heaps of not so friendly monkeys hanging around. Could be better but is a cheaper alternative to botanical gardens

It was a nice & easy trail among the beautiful nature! We didn't see any animal except  monkeys. But we heard noises of many birds during the trail & the trail was truly amazing. Although they didn't allow us to bring our bags in to the forest, they allowed foreigners to took their bags inside which was not fair.
This rainforest just behind the Temple of the tooth is nice to have an early morning walk. As soon as the forest awakes the city also wakes!

A very easy trail amongst breathtaking greenery. We saw and heard a wide range of wildlife, including a troop of monkeys. However, the toilet facilities were abysmal, especially considering that entry is paid.

We came to Udawattekele first thing in the morning, with my husband hoping to see some birds. There are plenty of trails. Unsurprisingly it was quiet at that time. While we didn't see too many birds it was still a wonderful place to walk around. While you are here be sure to track down the liana called pus wel. Its a giant vine believed to be between 200-300 years old! First thing in the morning before the morning mist had lifted, it made a weird and wonderul part of the forest. Also while you are here seek out the view point overlooking the city. It's lovely.

Truly called the green lung of Kandy, it's beautiful!! To know a tropical forest exists in this small town was truly mesmerising. You could walk inside without encountering another person for 30 minutes!! Tall trees give the requisite shade and the entire experience is serene and beautiful!!
The sanctuary was a lovely stop on our trip. A dense and beautiful forest a short drive from the town. Took us about 2 hours to hike the majority of the park. Would definitely recommend stopping.

We almost didn't come here having read some negative reviews, but we were really glad we did. There are some lovely old ladies at the gate and the cost was very reasonable (about £1.50 each I think). We walked around the whole forest which took a couple of hours at a slow pace. It is such a peaceful pace and there were few other people there. An oasis of calm right next to the hustle and bustle of Kandy. The sounds of the forest were fantastic but we only saw monkeys - lots of them - and some birds on our walk. There are many other animals here but they mainly emerge at night. Some people complained about the state of the path but with the exception of one small section in the south I would think you could wheel a wheelchair around the rest of the forest as there are good flat dirt roads most of the way round.

Nice walk around after the busyness of kandy. Unfortunately we saw no animals in the park (saw about 15 monkeys on the road walking up to the park) but still pleasent and cool in the shade to walk around

We walked here from town - take the first right off the main road with the Queens Hotel on the corner, takes 15 mins but last bit quite steep - and spent an idyllic couple of hours wandering around. Amazingly quiet after the noise of Kandy, and beautiful trees everywhere. Make sure you go to the lookout for great views of Kandy. We were lucky enough to see a large troupe of monkeys go barrelling down the hill, crossing the road right in front of us. Frustratingly the info board and leaflet tell you the main things you can see but not where they are!

Imagine a place ,a walk ,an hour where you wouldn't feel a thing of being inside a town .When it is Kandy ,the place is this small forest. Enter earliest in the morning with a walk there from the town . A minute at the ticket counter maintained by the Wild Life Dept and you are in for the solitude at of the forest morning. There are few Drives ,which were actually made by the British and aptly named after the wives of Governors at the time .A refuge to a plenty varieties of butterflies and the birds ,with a not so rare chance of an encounter with a  mountain Eagle perched on a tree , this little haven also is the resting grounds for  the last remnants of the once proud Kandyan Army- two troupes of monkey who rule the town. Ideal for small teams / no difficulty / 2 hours maximum / secured / Little chance of leech activity at some places / tour guide not needed /

Had a morning walk around the sanctuary, was a lovely start to the day! Various paths and routes to follow, with some gorgeous trees and rest spots, caves and lookout points. There's a pond there and various wildlife in the park, we saw some monkeys and a water monitor lizard! Well kept pathways and some basic toilets available as well. Watch out for leeches - best to wear shoes, not flip flops as we learned! But it was beautiful and shady, so the walk was comfortable even in the heat of Sri Lanka. Would recommend this over the botanical gardens.

We visited in the morning and spent about 2 hours walking. The paths are fairly well maintained. The forest is full of birdsong and is a respite from the noise and bustle of Kandy. We saw lots of monkeys, some deer, but not much else. The main entrance is a bit tricky to find, and the map isn't that accurate but it's small so difficult to get lost. The map implies there is a second exit near the temple, but this isn't the case (or at least we couldn't find it). The signs are pretty useless and the attractions they send you to are oversold - the viewpoint led up a winding path and ended, with no viewpoint! The hermitage 'cave" is a dark, slightly smelly rock cave filled with weird odds and ends! 662 rupees to get in, so well worth it and a delightfully antiquated ticketing system where an old lady handwrites your ticket, including your name and uses carbon paper (haven't seen that in ages). Worth a visit for some huge trees and tranquility.

This was a pleasant walk, mainly on the level and in the shade of trees. We only saw one deer and a few birds, but lots of monkey action including a turf war! Easy to find your own way around and a great view over Kandy at the southwest corner. Allow 2-3 hours with stops for monkey viewing. One toilet but no other facilities so bring water but in a non-disposable container.

A great escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. Once you enter the reserve its so peaceful with just the sounds of the animals, hard to believe how close to the city you really are. Nice easy stroll around the loop took around an hour. Nice to do the afternoon to get out of the intense heat and under the shade of the trees!

The best time we spent in Kandy was the walk in this forest reserve – we liked it much more than visiting the Tooth Temple and the Dance Show.  We were wondering whether leeches would be there, but we haven't seen any, despite the heavy rains a couple of days before our visit.  There were hardly any tourists there in the morning (around 9–10 am). We spent two hours walking there, before we didn't have much more time, but we could have spent three or more.
Great easy to follow paths around jungle area on edge of the city. Choice of 3km or 5km routes and the charming old lady at the entrance is only to happy to help. Its only 660 rupees
It is still a good place to walk in quietness and solitude.  However, the trails are not well maintained and there seems to general lethargy affecting the place.

The price when we visited was 650 per person (around 4 usd) which was totally acceptable. Compared with the botanical gardens it's cheap and we liked it way way more. It's a large and beautiful forest park, and we saw tons of diverse trees, monkeys, birds and even got lucky and saw two spooked deer! Definitely a highlight of our Kandy visit!

A lovely place for a quiet walk where you can spot a few birds and admire the huge trees. The route is about 5km if you follow the map right around There is a viewpoint where you can see the town of Kandy below. At certain points along the trail there are massively long lianas which cross the path. You can also spot monkjac deer, and of course some monkeys. Look out for an Asian Paradise flycatcher with its long orange plumage. If it rains, as it did for part of the time when we went, beware of leeches which might manage to get on your skin. The visitor centre has interesting facts that you can read. There is a modest entrance fee.

There’s only one entrance into this reserve so make sure you head to the right place. It shuts at 5pm, we got there at 4pm but the lady gave us a map and showed us the walk that would bring us back by 5pm. You have to leave where you come in. It was a very peaceful walk at that time. We didn’t see much wildlife apart from a few monkeys and birds but still very enjoyable walk. You have to pay a small entrance fee but it’s worth the money. There’s a great point to view kandy from on the walk and some good places to stop and take photos
Not too much to see but a cracking view half way around and nice and peaceful away from the hustle and bustle of Kandy. For £3 a person, worth it.

This is only just out of town but high up - you get several good views down over the lake and town.  It is a huge forest with enormous trees, excellent birdwatching, monkeys  and we also saw a wild pig. It is beautifully shaded to walk around but take plenty of water - despite a signpost to a cafeteria, we certainly didn't come across anything!  Very few people there when we visited - it was very peaceful.

My phone navigation was a little confusing - made it look like there were many entrances. But, in actuality, there is only one and the area is mostly fenced off from any other access. It makes for a pleasant walk in the heat of the day. A lot of mature trees with mature vines. You can see through the forest in every direction, but there are only a couple views outside the forest. I encountered monkeys that were fairly shy. I saw deer tracks in mud. There were other people walking. Everyone kept pretty quiet.

A wonderful walk through beautiful nature. The variety of trees in a space so close to the city was  interesting  and we did see a deer and of course many monkeys. Well worth a visit for some quiet peaceful time in Kandy

In the centre of Kandy - a real gem. Biodiverse as it comprises wet and dry zone species. Lovely few hours walk (start early), well trodden paths, fantastic bird life (a guide to identify species may be a consideration).

We couldn't believe this sanctuary exists so close to a bustling city like Kandy. Yes you can hear some vehicle noises but you're in Kandy! We saw wild boar, barking deer, lots of monkeys and birds. The walk is a little steep at the beginning but levels out and it loops around a large lake. We stopped at the information centre and spent some time watching the monkeys playing in the bamboo. The paths are wide and it will take an hour or so to view but we totally enjoyed it.

The map doesn't exactly match the actual paths but it's close enough, and not so large that you'll get lost anyway (you can always just retrace your steps). In a couple of hours we walked every path in the sanctuary. It's very peaceful and we only occasionally saw other people. It's a pleasant walk in the jungle and we saw plenty of wildlife.

This is promoted as a lush, quiet rainforest, but there are roads through it and some traffic noise. The forest is beautiful and of special note is a giant liana (vine) about the diameter of my let that cork-screws over a couple of acres of trees. Although there is wildlife here (deer, wild boar) I didn't see any and you should probably not expect to as the foliage is dense, though there is a lot of beautiful birdsong. Unlike the experiences of others, I didn't have any trouble with leeches, because the weather had been too dry for them. The signs were not very helpful to me, and I had to keep asking for directions to the way out. There were plenty of people around.

Steep climb up to the entrance but once inside the park it's pretty easy walking on wide pathways. Took about an hour to walk the loop. I entered at 4 pm and was under the assumption they closed at 6 pm. Glad I didn't dawdle, as when I exited at 5 pm it looked like they were waiting for me so they could lock the gate for the night. Summary: the walk was interesting but not really spectacular scenery. Saw a few monkeys but no other animals. There are some shady benches for resting/contemplation. Bathrooms had western toilets. I knocked the rating down a peg because of the price - not really worth 660 LKR. But if you're in Kandy and burning out on all the traffic and honking horns, and if you don't mind the entrance fee, it may be worth a diversion for a walk in the woods.

It was a rainforest created and preserved by the British Colonials where the film Bridge on the River Kwai was filmed with flying bats crowding the skies as the background. The flying bats are still there in thousands and so are many types of birds.

Considering we were in the sanctuary for around 3 hours, we didn't encounter many other people, and we couldn't believe we were still in Kandy. This is the perfect way to escape the hubbub of the city and see a lot of wildlife. We saw barking deer, lots of monkeys and lots of birds. Beware of leeches, wear socks and trainers!!
Beautiful forest with perfectly marked paths. There is a short 3km circuit or a longer 5km one. We spent a bit over an hour here. We saw loads of monkeys and some deer.

We spent an hour and a half walking and exploring beautiful Udawattekele. This had been on my bucket list for years and was so I glad to be able to check it off. Gorgeous plant life - interestingly shaped - branches and roots that reminded us of some magical show. We wore sturdy shoes and stayed on the paths. Saw three deer but since we were accompanied by 4 friendly but noisy dogs, didn't get to see anything else. I would highly recommend it. It is only 30  rupees for locals and about 6 $ for non locals.

A good place to get away from the noise of the city. This is a proper rain forest with wild animals who tend to run away and hide from humans. I saw monkeys, wild boar, and some deer, plus an eagle, hornbills, and other tropical birds. Bear in mind if you want to spot the wildlife here you need to BE QUIET and STILL. Its the first time I've been in a proper rain forest/jungle, and its pretty awesome. Like many others, I got leeched by 4 of the blighters. They don't hurt, but one of them latched onto a large vein on my foot which kept bleeding for a couple of hours afterwards.

Spent a couple of hours walking around the sanctuary and all we saw were a few monkeys. No birds at all. We did however get attacked by lots of leeches! Some local families were wandering around with children, this was probably the reason why there were no birds. Didn’t realise it was possible to make so much noise in a ‘sanctuary’!,

I spent two and a half hours walking around Udawattekele this morning and very pleasant it was too.  As others have said it’s hard to believe that your in the centre of Kandy.  In some places there is no traffic noise at all.  Deer and wild boar seem abundant and surprisingly unruffled by human presence.  Bird spotting is challenging given the high canopy but patience is rewarded - I saw hornbills and flycatchers amongst other birds. I cannot believe that some reviewers are complaining about an entrance fee of about £3 or €3.  Get real!  This is chicken feed and it all goes to help maintain the sanctuary. I did get leeched - on my foot and only discovered when I returned to my hotel and a very bloated leech fell on the floor as I took my trainers off.  If you’ve never had a leech attach itself to you it’s both painless and harmless.  Once they’ve had their fill (and it’s not very much of your blood) they simply detach themselves.  A bit messy but all part of life’s experience.
Typical forest, has walking paths inside. Good for a quick stroll or long walk. Makes sure to check the map/ask for the proper directions beforehand

Udawattekele was located near Kandy town area and shared tooth temple. Nice place to have a walk and have a super green experience. Many interesting stories were heard about this place and better if you can find and read them. You can't see more animals here in day time and it also depend on your luck :) It's the home for many beautiful birds and you hear how nice they are singing.

Interesting paths around the reserve.  Information signs useful.  Chance to see wildlife, monkeys quite frequent.  Careful as the leeches are sneaky. As in many parks, prices weird, 1322.50 for two adults and of course no change.
It has a beautiful view and if you are nature lover who loves to do hikes and all then this place is ideal

I can only describe this as a Woodland walk. When you enter the Forest there is a notice that gives you directions to all the different lengths of walks. The walk we did was not hilly but was easy. On the way there was a superb viewing point overlooking Kandy. I think we spent around 1.5 hours in the Forest and we saw deer, birds, butterflies and monkeys.
Sri Lanka is also famous for wild life and majority of the land is reserved for sanctury. This one is smaller one and you can sight monkeys, deers, wild boars and birds.. if lucky.

Bit disappointed by our visit here today. We had a lovely walk through the jungle and the view point over the city is lovely a peaceful (in my opinion even better than 'the' Kandy view point) however we saw very few wildlife. We had to really scour our surroundings as we walked to see three dear in the distance. Didn't see any birds or boar, despite looking around for ages. Not sure if it was the time of year, the fact it has rained, the time of day..m but we were walking around for just over two hours, really looking and being quiet and saw very little. Entry price was reasonable though and the history behind the reserve is interesting. So I don't regret going, just bit disappointed. Don't expect too much! You had to walk up a bit of a hill to get to the entrance but after that, not too hilly.

Udawattekele Sanctuary is not far from Kandy city. You can go there by walk in 10 to 15 minutes. The huge trees of this sanctuary reminds you a very thick huge forest that hundreds of km from the city but you are still in the city. If you are a nature lover you must visit this place. The whispering sound  of the shaking leaves and cicadas fill-up your mind in peace till your hear a whistle of a bird. The walking path of the sanctuary not hard. It's a easy walk in the nature. But don,t recommend to go there on rainy days. On raining days blood sucking leeches come out from the bushes. (I'm scared of leeches). And the other thing walking path become little muddy on rainy days. also slippery on the leaves. I'm a chauffeur for tourists.  so I never recommend my clients to go there on raining days. I've been to that place many many times. Visit that place for beautiful experience. Greets!

We were visited Kandy you should not miss the opportunity to spend a few hours in Udawattekele Sanctuary where you can see deer, wild boar monkeys and possibly some birds. As soon as you have aid your entrance fee you will see the rather muddy Royal Pond then you can wander on to the viewpoint and the information center before hiking round the other side and seeing the meditation caves. Actually this is really a beautiful forest and Silent environment mind free place. This place to near at Kandy lake and Sri Daladha Maligawa(Temple of Tooth).

The reserve also contains a great variety of plant species, especially lianas, shrubs and small trees. There are several giant lianas. Many of small and medium size mammals that inhabit Sri Lanka can be seen here.

The Udawattekele Sanctuary is an area of rainforest rich in species that have still been protected. The sanctuary consists of 160 acres of tropical rain forest and provides home for flora, fauna, birds and monkeys. Some of the birds that inhabit the Udawattekele Sanctuary are the Layards Parakeet, Sri Lanka Hanging Parrot, Yellow Fronted and Ceylon Small Barbets, Black Capped Bul Bul, Brown Capped Babbler, Emerald Dove and many more.

This trail is a must do if you are in Kandy early in the morning.Ticket counter opens at 8am.We were staying in a homestay at the backside of the entry point but it had a trail starting close by and we ended the trail at the entrance from where we started our day! We saw some wild boars and many monkeys with black ears and Langoors. Absolutely safe place too!
Lovely quiet spot for a morning's meandering.Didn't see too many animals but should we it's their territory.

We (my wife and I) booked this through the hotel we were staying at, the Cinnamon Citadel, Kandy. We only had a few hours to spare before moving south down the country and were glad we took this opportunity. We were picked up in a car at the hotel, and driven there in what only took about 15 minutes. It was early morning, roughly 7am, and the park was empty. Other than our guide we did not see anyone else. This made it all the more peaceful. If you're an early riser, i'd recommend going early. It lent itself to some wonderful scenes of mist clearing and the sun starting to break through the trees. Good photo opportunities. As others have said, there are plenty of monkeys going about their daily business. Additional wildlife we encountered included a deer, a few species of butterfly and a kingfisfer. One of the unexpected points of note, was the enourmous Puss-well (Giant Liana) tree. It's about 200 years old and spreads over an area of nearly 2 hectares. That information is thanks to a photo I took of the sign rather than my memory, but the way which the trees branches twisted and grew were certainly memorable and something i'd never seen before. There were longer routes to take, so you could spend more than the couple of hours we did, depending upon how much you enjoy such walks. The scenary within the forest was very good throughout and you also get to see some good views over Kandy at one point. Wildlife was intermittant, which was fine for us. The sections we did were fairly flat. There was one steep section to see a cave, which was optional rather than on the main route. If you book via that hotel, we found the guide Nithan to be very knowledgable. He is someone who is massively passionate about wildlife, and we got on to talking about his current research papers on plastics and how Sri Lanka might implement policies to address the amount currently impacting the wildlife in Kandy and beyond. Overall we throughlly enjoyed this and would happily recommend to enyone who likes fairly easy walks in a beautiful surrounding with a spot of wildlife.

Not far from one of the main attractions (the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic) and from the hustle and bustle of the city, this sanctuary is the perfect place to breathe easy and feast your eyes on some local flora. You can walk around for several hours, the ticket price is fair, and you'll find it much less crowded than for example the Botanical Garden in Peradeniya. Chances are high that you'll catch a glimpse of monkeys. While there's nothing spectacular awaiting you at Udawattekele, it offers a great opportunity for easy hiking, a spot to view the city below, and some old hermit monk dwellings.

Even tho our visit was short, it was a highlight of Kandy. We saw monkeys only. Perhaps mid-afternoon was not the best time to go. We did see a giant monitor lizard and a scorpion. The trees were magnificent. We walked past it at first, it is set back off the road by the side of a Buddhist edifice. The loos were nice. It was a bit expensive and getting past the bureaucracy in the hut was very amusing and colonial

Reading the review on this site we were very hesitant to go. But the forest is a really rewarding experience, The forest is beautiful, the paths are very easy to walk on and not artificial, so you have the feeling of being in a forest and not in a park. We were alone for most of the time. It’s definitely worth the couple of dollars of entrance fees.

If you need to escape the City, but don’t want to have to travel out too far or pay too much, then this is a great option. Easy to walk there and then walk around (I would say child friendly), it costs half of what the Botanical Gardens does (662 rupees)- it still annoys me when you have to pay to enter such places, but maybe I have been spoilt back home with free entry. Anyway, it is a very well preserved natural park full of wildlife. I saw deer, butterfly, monkeys and even an eagle soar overhead. You can hear so much more though. I spent a lovely 2 hours wandering around the paths and enjoying the view out across Kandy from the viewpoint. Really glad I went.

As a nature lover, this must be me favourite place in Kandy. Towering high trees and silence absorbs you into its warmth. Dunno who's genius ideas was to name signboards in Sinhala as most of the visitors are foreign. (irony)
located between beautiful ......green hills ........with lovely wind .....good walk wear proper comfortable peaceful walk with lots of wildlife
Perfect morning stroll with wildlife--- way to escape the busy overwhelming streets of Kandy. I absolutely loved this park--- it was a good walk around.

We had a wonderful walk at this place. There are a lot of fish in this water. We were giving them food and they were just coming close to us. We also had a beautiful view of this lake from our apartment.

We went to the sanctuary on a Monday morning and had a wonderful experience. We were literally the only people in the sanctuary aside from a couple workers cleaning the paths - it was very peaceful. We saw barking deer, monkeys, wild boars and heard and saw about a hundred bird species. The sanctuary is very well maintained. We spent about 3 hours there and think the money for entry was well worth it. You do not need a guide, although they may be able to provide explanation of the sanctuary’s history (we read about it before and after and found that was enough). The only thing to watch out for is the leeches. We only had an issue with this when trying to hike to the lookout (which in the end we couldn’t find - it may be overgrown by large trees now or we may have missed the trail as there are a few leading to the top). The leeches are quite small but easy to spot wriggling up your shoes. Spraying your shoes/feet and legs with insect repellent beforehand would solve this problem. It was also raining a little off and on while we were there so you may not have this issue on dry days. Enjoy the sanctuary and keep it as clean as it was when we visited!

A nice walk in the forest but cost to foreigners is now about 1100 rupees ($10) and not worth it.  We may have been unlucky as saw or heard few birds. Saw monkeys. Nice view over Kandy from top. Paths are well kept and clean, and quiet place to walk but way way too expensive and had to argue with booth personnel for change.  He had change but did not want to give it out.
While enjoying the beauty of the forest, we can cycle along the marked trails through the forest. This would be an unforgettable experience for anyone.

This is a lovely forest close to Kandy town. As the streets are so busy we loved the opportunity to be able to walk around freely. The entrance fee for two of us was 1350 rupees. We saw lots of gorgeous monkeys and had some friendly dogs walk with us for awhile. My husband also saw a large snake cross the path (maybe 2m)!! The track is easy and not muddy, we were fine in flip flops.  I was a little bit worried after the snake sighting but I'm sure it's fine if you stick to the paths.

go as early as possible, few pleasures of Kandy can match the beauty of the long walk in Udawaththekele in the Morning. leave behind the camera and let the foliage ,the greenery and chirping of birds dive in to the mind.The jungle seductively envelops the self ,leaving virtually zero sense of the bustling town.. an excellent array of butterflies and the occasional mountain eagle perched on a branch ,getting ready for the day's chores would not miss the eye.
It is hard to imagine you are so close to the noise and bustle of Kandy city centre as you walk through along the paths of this former royal forest.  It makes a cool peaceful interlude in sightseeing

If you are visiting Kandy you should not miss the opportunity to spend a few hours in Udawattekele Sanctuary where you can see deer, wild boar monkeys and possibly some birds. As soon as you have aid your entrance fee you will see the rather muddy Royal Pond then you can wander on to the viewpoint and the information center before hiking round the other side and seeing the meditation caves. This is really a beautiful forest which shelters you from the heat of Kandy, and gets you away from the polluted city due to exhaust fumes. there are plenty of benches to rest on and you will see many monkeys.

This should really feature much higher on the list of things to do! It’s a lovely hours walk around the jungle and it’s in the middle of the city!! Saw some monkeys and jungle dear and the vegetation is amazing just look out for leaches. The only annoying thing was that they wouldn’t let me go on my own so the tuk tuk driver had to come with me - for safety - as I’m just a woman...grrr

We spent 2 hours waliking in this Forrest which is basically located right above the temple of the tooth, but is unknown to most tourists. We Saw wild boars, monkeys, birds. There is a great viewpoint over the lake & city. It is a really relaxing activity to do to escape Kandys pollution and noise. Recommended!

This is a jungle nature reserve just a stones throw from the busy centre.  It felt as though we were the only people there.  You can walk for miles through it.  There is a rangers hut with an interesting display of the wildlife you may see.
A peaceful place to escape the city and go walking in the forest Lots of birds and monkeys A pleasant series of trails exist which vary from about a mile up to three miles in length

Went to the entrance by tuk tuk and then walked one of the trails on the map we were given. Huge trees with amazing lianas trailing over them. Great treat was a large group of monkeys crossing the path and completely ignoring us whilst playing / squabbling amongst themselves

There is a minimal entry fee, but it is well worth it for an awesome morning walk among Sri Lankan nature. The trails were easy to navigate and we saw numerous deer and monkey's. There are different trail options, but we spent just over an hour or so exploring the "jungle." It is mostly shaded, so makes for a nice leisurely stroll or jog. We ran into a few other folks along the way, but not too many. This was well worth our time and gave us a serene break from the somewhat other chaos of Kandy!

How to get there by foot: Indentify Kandy municipality council on the map and walk there. The building will be on your left, you continue up on that main street. A panel will then point you in the direction of the entrance (always straight on anyway). The entrance fee is only 30LKR for Sril Lankan people. But for the "foreigners", who are of course very wealthy, it is 660LKR, which is "only" 22 times the normal price. Wouhou! Nevermind... you are now in the forest, and you can enjoy the walk. We spend 2 hours and saw lots of deers and monkeys. However, it is a forest, nothing special, and you can generaly walk in any forest in the world for free. The only reason we went there is because we had so extra time to spend in Kandy, but if you skip it, you won't miss anything. PS: for the amount of money they get from the "foreigners", they could at least clean the toilets (just after the entrance, on the left). They are absolutely disgusting and have never been clean, that's for sure.

I travelled in the late morning when there are people scattered in the park. A lone local man wandering around and asked me if I have water. Quite strange already. Then he followed me into a small dirt trail to a view point (with no view actually). Luckily there were a couple there. After that he followed me to like every single corner! And he seems to know the park really well so that he knew to take a short cut when I walked very fast to try to get rid of him. I made sure I was not mistaken by waiting and let him pass and retrieved to the crossing and saw him coming back. I did not know what he wanted. Finally I went with other travellers and exit the park. This totally ruined my experience of the park. I wrote this to warn other female solo traveller especially physically small like me to be very careful when you visit this park.

If you get tired of all the urban hustle and bustle, this forest sanctuary is exactly what you need. It is literally a piece of a rainforest right in the middle of the city. Simply the umbral paths, listen to numerous birds and observe the wildlife. Visit it early morning for best experience, as you will enjoy the incredible misty atmosphere with beautiful rays of light breaking through the canopy. You will also pretty much have the entire forest for yourself, as there’re no tourists there in the morning. The entrance price for foreigners is a tad too high though and it seems to only get higher as time goes by.
Beautiful location with many varieties of trees and plants five minutes walk from the busy kandy city good location to get away from the city pollution

Spent a couple of hours exploring this park. Once past the entrance we weren’t inundated by monkeys and could enjoy the walk. As many people have said, the map they give you is useless, as is google maps. The cave was super creepy.
This udawattekel is on the Kandy Lake . As I said all these buildings  are well kept and painted  white. It on the lake  and I dud not visit inside.
We had a lovely walk in this jungle. In the space of just an hour we saw terrapin, barking deer, wild boar and a variety of birds.

Quiet forest with low visitor numbers in Kandy. Good place for a walk, the paths were hilly  in places. Did not see any inside but the paths inside appeared to have been used by vehicles. Not much wildlife at the time (late in the day). Lots of tall tropical trees (some in flower), few local fruit trees, vines, a large waterhole were seen. This was effectively a small rain forest area, good for a few hours of walking.

We visited for three and a half hours. It cost 1255 rupees for two of us to enter. As usual locals got served first, so it took a while to get through. You get given a map but it’s not detailed so take a photo of the large map on a board on your left just as you go through. It details both routes you can walk. Easy to follow though there are some signs to direct you. Toilets near the entrance but really filthy and full of used sanitary products so I chose to pee in the woods! Take water as there’s nowhere to buy any refreshments. The forest is beautiful. We saw hundreds of monkeys very close up as they have no fear of humans. One stole my boyfriends lunch! We saw a deer too and heard many birds. The paths are easy to walk, I managed fine in flipflops. A welcome break from the traffic and easy to walk to from town. About 20 mins walk from the temple of the tooth relic.

A must see place for lovers of nature. The map isn't the best but part of the experience... Lots of places to explore and find ... A great few hours enjoying nature at its best. Not many people which helped make it enjoyable. We took a tuk tuk up and walked back down from the entrance.
Very nice park just in the middle of the city. We saw some wildlife and had a quiet morning walking around.

Took a 3 hr walk around the place. They need a better map, but i managed to find my way back to the entrance okay.  There is only one entrance into the park even though it looks like there are roads that go up into it from just beside the temple - the guards will let you know if you are wrong.

It is kind of strange to take a walk in the jungle in the middle of the city, but Udawattekele offers just that. The paths are in the shade underneath the canopies, and there are quite a few birds around. Most of them are just heard, but sometimes, they can be spotted as well (bring binoculars). We didn't see any mammals but the toque macaques, but I understand they are there somewhere.

The sanctuary is a forest reserve located to the north of the Dalada Maligawa (Temple of the Tooth) From the city centre it takes about 10mins to get to the entrance by vehicle. Entrance depends on whether you're a local or a foreigner. I see quite a few tourists complaining about the different prices, but that's how tourism works. Not only in Sri Lanka, but all over Asia. The forest is a paradise for flora & fauna & there are wild boar, monkeys, monitor lizards, water monitors, porcupines, kingfishers, owls, cranes, & many other birds, insects & flowers. Walk around & explore nature while listening to the multitude of chit chat of the birds. Please be aware that you're in a forest in a tropical country. If the ground is wet, you're going to have leeches, so be prepared. The forest maintenance has improved along the years, but certain things such as the directions & the garbage handling could improve. It's still a lovely place to visit & I highly recommend it to locals & foreigners alike.

We came here to escape the hustle and bustle of the city. Spent a lovely couple of hours walking the trails, mainly shaded by the gorgeous trees which was a welcome relief. Saw lots of monkeys and a huge water monitor. Great viewpoint of Kandy and the lake. Nice to visit for a few hours respite!

I love this hidden gem! Relatively unknown by tourists or those who do know about it don't think it's worth going to. But i loved it! I would recommend taking a tuk tuk up to the sanctuary as the reserve entrance is up a rather steep hill which isn't ideal when you're about to walk around a forest. Within minutes of entering the hustle and bustle of the city disappears and all you can hear is the birds and insects around you. There was a group of monkeys hanging around at the entrance trying to steal food from a group who were leaving but they weren't aggressive or trying to steal sunglasses etc, i would still watch out though. Quietness is key and you'll be surprised how much comes out of the forest when you let it come to you. I saw a couple of barking deer, LOADS of birds and I had a close encounter with another group of monkeys who played around my feet and ran up to sniff my bags and climbed the trees beside me. There are a few different path circuits you can take so you can spend as much or as little time there as you want. I spent almost 4 hours there and only left because I ran out of bottled water! There isn't anywhere to buy food or water so bring your own. There are places to sit and have a picnic if that's what you'd like. The forest information centre is great also with a chap who will talk you through the area and things to look out for.

If you want to get away from the buzz of Kandy for a couple of hours, you can take a nice walk there. We saw some deer, turtles and fish in the pond by the entrance. There is also a German Buddhist monk there who does not mind visitors. It is safe and the paths are in good condition.
Lots of monkeys there.Calm and quite place to enjoy nature.We saw some deers and wild pigs also.But washrooms are not clean.Anyway it's good place to visit(nature lovers)

Highly recommended!!! This park is a peacefully place in Kandy. I really love trees. So this was the perfect place for me. (Giant liane) We had also a lot of fun with the map. Because it is not the best one. So you go arround and you never know where you are.

We visited around 3pm following a busy day roaming around Kandy town. As you walk up the hill past Trinity College you leave the hustle and bustle of Kandy behind and are met with peace; bar the sounds of nature. We followed a circular route around the sanctuary for a couple of hours seeing no one and enjoying the tranquility. Towards the end of the circuit you can go down to a beautiful viewing spot with stunning views over the city-perfect for sun set! As we returned the sun was setting and animals began to come out of hiding to feed and drink. We saw barking deer, boar and of course some cheeky langur monkeys. A wonderful, relaxing experience worth every rupee!

This place is situated behind 'Dalada Maligawa' (The Temple of Sacred Tooth Relic). It was used as a royal forest park for the royal family. Nowadays it has named as a sanctuary due to its natural and archeological values. The thing is, this place is not very recommended for average travellers, since there is not much interesting things to see. But the place is so calm and good for a long walk. And the city view point has a nice view. But for real a nature lover this place have a lot to offer, like giant bamboo, giant liana, etc. It has a rich floral diversity, but not much of animal diversity.

We took a lovely walk along the trails of this lovely national park, enjoyed the greenery, the peaceful ambiance and the view of the city and pond below. Hard to believe such a gem is right in the heart of the city. You can choose the length of the trek you take. Advise the map handed at the entrance.

This can be the only forest situated in a commercial city. This has a thick forest cover all around the area and situated next to The Kandy temple.  Once you enter the forest reserve you feel like you are entering in to an airconditoned room. It's so cool and only notice that you can hear is from the birds signing.  Also there is a meditation center inside the forest. Some Buddhist monks practice meditation inside this Jungle and it is less crowded
Must see place during your visit to Kandy, Ideal place to just to do a relaxing walk, bird watching, short trek or visit to the hermitage in the forest.
Nice place. Peaceful. Good for the travrller who loves nature. There is nothing much  to see or do. Good placefor meditation.

The park visit involves a ticket and the office gives you a map to traverse the park. The park as such is not very clear in terms of routes and way and does not have much to do. It does have some good view points to see Kandy Lake and click a few pictures.
This is good for group travelers and solo travelers too. Not far from kandy town 5 min drive or fifteen min walk will brng you here. Can experience wildlife and you can visit some ruins too

A short drive from the Temple of Tooth, Kandy, the Udawatta Forest is truly a sanctuary. There are more than one walking routes, 3km, 5 km and 7 km. No cycling only walking. There is a small charge of Rs 30 per adult which is truly peanuts. Kandy's cool weather makes it an easy walk to do.  The HUGE, and I mean HUGE trees along the way will take your breath away. There is a city view point which gave a beautiful view of the Kandy town and the lake. The forest makes you feel like a set of Planet of the Apes due to the sheer number of monkeys there....and they do follow you jumping from tree to tree in a thrilling reenactment of the movie. The little things were not aggressive at the same time we did not take any chances either...held on to our cameras and kept a watchful eye. The place is an environmental bliss with a lot of photo opportunities. The place has toilet facilities however in true SL style, they were wet.

What a fantastic find just a short walk away from the crazy Kandy town! Grab some snacks and head here for a peaceful picnic amongst some fabulous fauna and flora. Udawattekelle boasts everything from butterflies to giant bamboos. If you enjoy a good wander in the woods, you'll love these windy walkways. The signs are sweet sentiment although they don't really point you in the right direction ! Don't worry all roads lead to home, or in this case the gate, so enjoy getting lost in mother nature's finest!
A great chance to escape the kandy chaos. Really peaceful walks in the shade. A chance to look out over kandy too which is a great photo opportunity. There is a fee for entry
Nice walk through forest/jungle. Managed to see a few monkeys close to the entrance, but apart from that there wasn't much else. Recommended if you have a few hours spare.
Saw monkeys at the start but apart from that the wildlife was pretty limited. A good thing to do if you a have a few hours spare in your day

Our driver recommended this spot. The rainforest was originally only for the royal family and was 1000 acres at one stage. It's now 267 acres and describes itself as Kandy's lungs (which it really needs). We wandered here for 1.5hrs but you could spent much longer. If you follow signs for garrison cemetery you get to a lookout over the city. The conservation hut had great displays and even better there was a dept of forestry employee who talk about each of the displays and what the dept hope the achieve by re-extending the forest in the future. The birds chirping and easy spotting of barking deer and monkeys was a welcome contrast to the noise below.

You are in the jungle there are no real views however we saw a cobra, a python, deer and wild boar, and monkey. Also got bitten a million times by Mosquito's, it is not particularly picturesque but its good to kill a couple of hours if you have them.

Sorry to say it wasn't worth the entrance fee (660 LKR). We saw two water monitors playing in the lake which was cool. Other than that- got attacked by leeches (!) and lost the track couple of times due to the misleading signs. Would not recommend.

A real forest full of intact old & traditional trees. It is huge and you can spend up to 3 hours walking & climbing. A tour guide is needed not to get lost and to explain about some details inside the sanctuary. Nice museum inside.
We were able to watch animals but it wasn't quite what we expected it to be. was boring.. but still we saw a lot of animals.. if you're an animal lover its a place for you.
Saw monkeys, barking deer, wild boar and a wide range of birds a peaceful place I. The heart of a bustling city.

After reading the reviews I was a bit nervous there would be thousands of leeches and even after a bit of bush bashing we came out leech free. We took our bikes around the 3km loop which was really fun. The forest was actually really nice for being surrounded by a large city, although not really the kind of place to go if you are expecting to see heaps of wildlife. There were lots of monkeys, butterflies, a deer, some turtle, fish but that's about all. Not so much in the way of birdlife. Worth checking out though for a nice stroll.

Our tourist map shows this as Udawattakale Bird Sanctuary, so we mistakenly went for bird watching.  One hears lots of birds, but even the birding guide with us could not see them.  If you are looking for a nice walk through a forest, you will not be disappointed.

We visited the Royal Forest Patk, Udawattakele, yesterday morning and spend a couple of hours wandering around the interesting trails. It's a lovely rest from the sun, as the majority of the trail is shaded by the trees. We saw monkeys, wild boar, deer, birds & butterflies within the forest park and only a few other people. There are a couple of places to stop, admire the nature and perhaps have a picnic (although you might have to watch out for food-stealing monkeys). The park is definitely worth the 650 rupees fee (£3.25 - the price of a coffee in England) & you are given a map upon payment. The city viewpoint has lovely views of the lake and this is the first point we saw a family of wild boars. From here we tried to go down a trail that pointed to Garison Cemetery (on the park map), however a man called to us from the top of the stairs, saying it was out of the park grounds and we couldn't enter, so we turned back. Next we tried to find Kodimale flag point (the highest point of the forest), there was a sign pointing us in the right direction from the main track, success! But after following this track we found a five way fork with no further sign... we walked down a few of these paths but couldn't see to find the flag point. There is also a temple on the map however the route down to this was closed of, we did however find some of the caves which were interesting to see. In terms of nature & an enjoyable walk I would give the forest four stars, but because some of the points of interest in the park seemed difficult to find/we weren't permitted to see, (perhaps could do with a few more signposts,) I gave it three. Definitely would still recommend as an enjoyable way to spend a couple of hours.

Udawatta Kale is one of my favourite places in Kandy. If you are the type who loves taking a silent stroll in the woods, get lost in the past or dream aimlessly, with just the sound of your own footsteps & leaves dancing in the wind, then this is the ideal place for you. I always make sure that I go for at least a short walk whenever I visit this ancient city, Kandy. One thing I always miss, is the Garrison Cemetery inside the forest. Definitely next Time :)) Entrace ticket: Rs30 - 20/02/16

Recommended for the people who loves a good quiet walk into the wild. a ticket should be bought first (as for now being priced at Rs.600/ US $ 4) The ideal time would be in the morning, make sure to pack something for lunch. The trails and all the information required can be gained from the office. The map can be misleading at times but don't worry follow the roads or the desire paths and you won't be lost. There are Buddhist temples along the way, wild boars, deer, lots of monkeys, birds and grizzled giant squirrels are few of the things you will see.

An old royal forestpark today open for public for a fee of cirka 650 rupies. I do not argue the fee because I guess they need money to maintain the accessebility to the park. As a tourist you get a little folder with a map. This map and som extra googlemap ;-) was nice to have when walking the roads and paths leading thru the park. Plenty of monkeys (very calm) and butterflies but not much else of fauna. The flora is nice but not exceptional (i visited in april pretty warm and dry). I enjoyed the park just taking it easy and enjoying the shade. Well worth a visit. The entrypoint is from de westside of the park.
had a wonderful time in a cool place never been to a place like this with lots of monkies and had a wolk around

Udawatte kelle sanctuary often spelt as Udawattakele is a historic forest reserve on a hill ridge in the city of kandy it was a forest reserve in 1856 and then declared a sanctuary in1938. it's easily accessible from the city of kandy a short walk to the entrance from the main road  i did the whole walk around the pathe which are named and numbered the trees are really tall like in a rain forest i also sow so many types of bird s and wild boar was also lucky to see a snake but not poisonous. i also visited the little museum that tells you almost everything about the place .it was fully worth the entrance fee of rs. 600
You will see everything you can see inside on the way there(giant bamboo, wild boar, monkeys..). 600rs per person??! Give me a welcome drink or something!

It is amazing that there is this large nature sanctuary just a stone's throw away from the hustle and bustle of Kandy town.  We had a lovely 2 hour hike around this peaceful forest.  Wonderful trees and we saw a deer and some wild boar, as an added bonus.  Be warned however.  The map that you get give is terrible and the sign posts along the path are misleading, but forget about getting from A to B in a hurry.  Meander and take in the sights.  Lovely.
Quiet and serene forest within the city of Kandy. Be quiet and take in the surroundings. We saw deer and lots of dogs.
Great place to get a good hike in and see some gorgeous views with monkeys all around.  Maybe better sign postings as it's very easy to go off trail

This place is beautiful , full of amazing sounds from the animals and was a welcome escape from the heat and noise of Kandy. It's unbelievable that this gem has such a busy city on its doorstep. We went mid afternoon and walked around for a couple of hours.
The place has a pathway and trail to walk around but other than a couple of vista points wherein you could see the Tooth Temple and Kandy Lake from far the place overall is not much.

If you travel Kandy, do not miss this place. You can see the largest Creeper in Sri Lanka in this jungle. Place is really amazing. It is ideal to travel in sunny hot days. There is small lake in the jungle and "Lovers' Walk" situated by the lake.

This is a place where you have to be prepared to walk. There are no wardens or people to direct, the signs don't give helpful tips like distance to destinations. There are wild animals if you are patient enough to watch and wait. Be mindful of the monkeys, they're very tame but still, if you have food, they might grab

We caught the bus into the city and then walked to the forest. The paths are well marked although we found the map given to us on entry slightly difficult to follow. Lovely walk, really peaceful place with lots of clean air which is much needed after the pollution of kandy traffic. We saw lots of monkeys, deer and turtles in the lake. Missed the wild boar unfortunately. One of the nicest places we visited in kandy.

Had a nice walk through here keeping off the hottest of the day's sun. Plenty of monkeys for entertainment. The walk could benefit from some extra signage/better maps as we managed to get a bit lost (as did several others we met) near the German Hermitage. But other than that it was very pleasant.

Udawattekele can be reached by walking from Kandy but it is uphill, a tuktuk cost us £1.50 and we walked back down. The forest has well marked tracks to follow, is quiet and shaded and very enjoyable. We were there early afternoon and did not see many birds or animals but still appreciated the peace and quiet.

This is a nice area that you easy reach with tuk-tuk. There are good paths so you can walk with a stroller. Nice forest and fine viewpoint over Kandy. Monkeys, pigs, deer, turtles, water monitor were observed.
Spent an afternoon walking around in the park. Saw a bunch of monkeys, some deer and wild boar. Lovely walks in the woods.

OUTSTANDING!  I'd call it the monkey preserve and it was awesome. We showed up at 4:30pm and were about the only visitors there. We paid our admittance fee and only got into the park about 100 feet before we found monkey heaven. There were monkeys everywhere and it was a group of at least 75 monkeys. At first they startled us because they were grabbing our legs and it felt like pinching.  Very scary. Then our guide said to carry a small stick about 0.5 meters and when the monkeys get too close, simply show the stick or drag it on the ground and the monkeys will back off. It worked like a charm. DO NOT hit the monkeys or they will ALL attack you. Just wave the stick, do not touch the monkeys with stick. The monkey kingdom is located just inside the entry gate and go left at the first turn in the road and then walk another 30 feet and you will be swarmed in monkeys. They are so cool!  We spent the entire 45 minutes in that one area enjoying the monkeys and taking awesome pictures. If you want to see lots of monkeys, then this place is the best!

We arrived late, about 4:45 pm. The park closes at 6 pm, so we weren't sure it was worth buying a ticket but it was our last day in Kandy. So glad we did, as we started to walk around the lake the monkeys surrounded us and some of them started to grab our ankles playfully. Our local driver noticed and instructed us to carry a stick to intimidate them with, not to actually hit them or they could attack. It worked great and my husband got a huge kick out of it. This place turned out to be one of his favorite things off the day, even though we didn't actually walk the entire park.

If you have an hour or two to spare whilst visiting Kandy I would highly recommend making a stop at Udawattakele! The entrance fee is around 550 rupees, and this entitles you to a 3-4km walk around the forest area, there are even wild monkeys all over the forest which was so lovely to watch. My only criticism is that the sign posts are very poorly labelled and I got lost a few times!
i got to get there with my college friends last year. you must buy a entrance ticket when you enter  and can hire a guide if needed.

We went with our elementary aged children. There are broad and smooth dirt road type paths, as well as hiking trails. There are lots of monkey, and even vines you can swing on. We had a very nice time; I'd like to return. There are bathrooms scattered throughout, but no drinking water.

Udawattakele Royal Forest Park is an amazingly tranquil haven just above the cultural centre of Kandy. It is tamed jungle with a number of well constructed paths running through it. I was very impressed by the giant liana and we saw monkeys and a deer. The entrance fee of about $10 for the two of us was a bit steep but fine if the money goes to preserving this magic area. Also a nice temperature being very shady.

We walked here from Kandy lake having done the temple of the tooth relic first. We'd bought a packed lunch and so whilst it was completely the wrong time of day to see much wildlife it was a lovely shady meander in the heat of the day. We did see wild pig - mum and 8 babies! Monkey, turtles and a few birds. Watch out for the map, its not quite ummm to scale? or really all that similar to the actual layout but its useable :)

If you are planning to go there, get prepared to pay 650 rupee at the entrance, this came as a big surprise to me as this is almost half what you would pay to enter the infamous temple of the tooth located in the same city. It is a 15 minute walk from the temple of the tooth, last stretch is a walk uphill. There is a gate and a guard charging tourists at the entrance which I found very opportunistic and unpleasant, especially that price asked is expensive Sri Lanka standards and you are given nothing in return. Inside, there are paths between trees leading to a lake. You can also see birds and monkeys along the way. (Big area) If you have time to kill in Kandy and feel like a walk in nature, go for it, but to be honest, I think there is plenty of beautiful natural places to check out in Sri Lanka without having to pay an entrance fee!
It is unbelievable that this sanctuary is so close from.the city and so peaceful and serene.  There are parts where you only hear birds...

This is a hidden gem in Kandy.  Good place to walk and enjoy a beautiful forest.  Map can be a bit misleading.  We passed the turnoff point to the look out and had to backtrack.  The tree canopy keeps the sunlight out so it is a cool and relaxing walk.

I visited this forest for a few hours and it was quite nice. It is amazingly dense and green, and there are beautiful lizards and birds to see. It is a very nice trail to follow in a loop. The most extraordinary sight was the hermitage caves at the outskirts, because of some strange reason there was the sad remains of a cement buddha there, with human bones sticking out from it. I’ve never seen anything like it. That eerie place with strange symbols, broken walls and noisy cicadas made my day.

Away from the chaos of a dirty city is this jungle sanctuary. Nothing too special, but peaceful and a beautiful environment of trees. The amazing liana that stretches for two hectares is a real treat. Cool in the midday heat

Located above the city of Kandy, the sanctuary is ideal to get away from the noisy roads of Kandy and relax in between of hundreds of differents plants. Pricing is a little lottery, we paid 1.325 LKR for 2 persons. You can either walk up there (30 minutes from CC) or take a TukTuk for ~300 LKR. The main walk through the sanctuary is about 4 km long.

This jungle or forest is really close to Kandy. I loved it to walk around. Monkey's, birds and a deer is saw. The park is really nice but not a lott of people go there so it's good to relax and get away from the busy town. Tip, bring water and food there is nothing in or near the entrance to buy. Easily 1-2 hours of walking around.

A amazing place to visit and escape the madness of Kandy city. Reasonable entry price when you can spend all day in there encountering wild monkeys, a whole hosts of birds, and deer. There are also a number of different hermitages scattered around the woods so mindful to be respectful while in the area. Kandy view point is located in here as well near the cemetery with stunning views over Kandy lake and city. We visited on a rainy day and although we had to wear waterproofs before we got in, once you enter the sanctuary, the tree cover is so heavy you don't really need them. Also there is only one bathroom as you enter - not the best or cleanest (don't expect toilet paper!) but better than going in the bush and getting leeches somewhere  they shouldn't be!

We had a really wonderful 3 hours here with a very good driver & vehicle.
