We think we saw every available animal the park had to offer , right down to amazing little dug beetles doing their work in the middle of the road. This was our 3 park in this area & well worth a visit. The water holes & lakes make this not only great for the animals but very good for the visitors as well. We recommend you visit this park
A beautiful sanctuary in the middle of the hustle and bustle, beautiful scenery lots of wildlife, to quote a famous aussie movie "Ah the serenity"

This sanctuary is located just behind the kandy town. You can even walk from the busy town to get their. It's like a different world just close to the town with hustle and bustle . Filled with tropical trees and various climbers and beautiful birds and monkeys.

We saw monkeys outside but not in the sanctuary, and saw deer, hog and birds inside. Take water and snacks with you as you cant buy any there, and wear trousers and trainers to avoid any bites as youre in the woods.

The true beauty of the sanctuary cannot be rushed, and honestly, best visited with a specialist who knows its rich history.  You need to take time to walk, meander along its many generally unexplored paths. Be warned though it can get quite dangerous for someone who is not used to a proper hike.  If so, stick to the demarcated path which is perfectly safe. If you ar win Kandy, an absolutely brilliant trek to truly get away from it all, and at times, discover yourself !

We stayed in Kandy two nights but only really had one day. Kandy town itself is quite overwhelming, very busy, dusty and dirty. Generally in Sri Lanka the people are friendly, welcoming and kind, however we found many people in Kandy (and certainly not all) quiet rude and always trying to con tourists. For example tuk tuks should cost around 100 rupees per mile but we were charged 500 rupees to go from town to the sanctuary (just over a mile). I know you are expected to negotiate however the people here seem to have gotten wind of prices in the U.K. and the west generally and just charge whatever they think you will pay. To some extent I don't mind paying more as a tourist however here you get the impression that the locals are enjoying conning you. The sanctuary was a nice way to get out of the town. It was quiet and peaceful and offered a quick getaway from town. We only really saw monkeys in the park and there was nowhere to buy water. There are toilets but they aren't the nicest.. there was also quite a lot of rubbish around the place which was a shame as the monkeys were playing with the plastic bottles. The entrance fee is 650 rupees (approximately £4ish) which is very reasonable however the local entry cost which is listed at the door is 30 rupees (20p) another example of how people seem to think here. Again I really don't mind paying double or even triple the local cost as a tourist but twenty times the cost is crazy especially when the same goes for food, transport and accommodation. The prices are higher in other cities for a reason, the place is clean and sewage is not flowing through the streets! If you do need to go to Kandy the park is worth a visit but if going to Sigiria rock or attractions in the north then stay closer to them for a more enjoyable day trip and to avoid Kandy town.

A great walk. I would advise to take a tuk tuk to the entrance or you  will be exhausted climbing to reach it before you even get in. Walk back to the lake when you come out. Beautiful place, no one else around, we didn't see any birds or wild pigs at all, only lots of monkeys by the monastery and caves. Hot an humid, take some salt with you, if you get leeches stuck to your skin, don't pull them out, sprinkle salt on them and they will drop off. You cannot beat the view of Kandy and the lake from this sanctuary viewpoint.
Spent the morning here, perfect to escape the busy city despite it being so close to the centre. Could do a variety of walks the longest being 5km. Saw various wildlife including lots of monkeys.

Udawattekelle is situated  in the ancient hill capital of srilanka . (Kandy ) It is one of the interesting  tracking  place . When you go inside the jungle can get unfogetable  experience .it is amazing .

This is a wonderful place to escape from the noise and traffic of Kandy. Just a short walk from the centre of town, you get to see local wildlife including monkeys, deer and maybe a snake or two. There is a brilliant view of the town from the viewpoint. Take water and enjoy a few hours away from it all....
It was great to see this place very clean and the very destructive monkeys around and most of the protected trees and plants was lucky to see some barking deer.

This is a beautiful jungle retreat in the heart of bustling Kandy. Really worth the 650 LKR entrance fee, and providing you go when it is dry there is a very obvious path with no leeches in sight. The view over Kandy at point 4 on the map is worth the admission price alone. However, do NOT go to the washroom where. The men's are 'OK', but the women's are in some kind of faeces-strewn dungeon. Seriously, avoid at all costs. Also, take some bottled water with you, as they don't sell any in the park.
It is near by Kandy city centre. You can walk there. It is quiet place where you can rest and beautiful view on Kandy.

Quite a walk on a hot day, but SO worth it for all the wonderful macaques - we observed 3 different families and were awe struck by them. Wear proper walking shoes/boots and stay on the main paths and out of the wetter undergrowth to avoid the much-reviewed leeches.

Udawattekele sanctuary located just behind the tooth of temple in Kandy. it has well organize path for walking and cyclical tour. some of the endemic birds, monkeys, wild bore, and many reptiles...etc..

This was one of our first experiences of the Sri Lankan countryside and we saw lots of interesting wildlife including monkeys, deer, turtles, snakes etc.  Definitely worth a visit, the only thing was that the signage was a little poor and we didn't go to all the places we wished to.

After a morning being squashed at the Temple of the Tooth the Udawattekele Sanctuary was an oasis of calm. The walk through the forest was almost deserted apart from some monkeys, wild pigs and lots of butterflies. The viewpoint over Kandy was worth a visit as was the small visitor's centre which gave some information about the local wildlife. Despite being given a small map we managed to get lost as the signage is not good and the map is useless. However we thoroughly enjoyed the walk. make sure you wear sensible shoes as leeches lurk in the undergrowth.

Worth going for the walk alone but don't hold out for much wildlife. We saw a few monkeys, a deer and a few birds but thats about it. The view of Kandy is great though. Don't fret about getting lost, though the sinage is terrible all paths lead to Kandy!

Amazing place. Quite unbelievable that Kandy city hosts such a great forest. Very clean and evergreen. The best place to look for tranquility in Kandy. Apart from the giant flora and fauna, the forest possesses a Kandy view point, a temple, a few caves, giant liana etc. There are some unfair restrictions for locals. No unmarried couples would be allowed inside and no food or bags would be allowed as well. No such restrictions for foreigners. Tickets 650LKR for foreigners and only 30LKR for locals. A must visit if you are travelling to hill country.

This is worth a visit and is an easy stroll through beautiful forest. I'm not sure why people complain of leeches because the main track is actually a dry dirt road fit for cars to drive on. Maybe it's different after a lot of rain, but just make sure you wear covered shoes. There are options of going off the main track into the forest for a more challenging hike and in that case you might want to be more covered up. It was a very easy 5km walk to go the whole way around on the main track. We didn't see any animals or birds other than 2 separate groups of macaques that were on the track. Im a little afraid of macaques and don't like going near them. Both times, the larger leader of the troupe came close to check us out but they mostly kept their distance from us. I've learnt it's always best not to feed them or show them you have any food at all. I don't look at them directly and just keep walking. There were deer or boar tracks everywhere so there must be quite a few animals in the forest, but it was a public holiday and maybe too many people around. It really wasn't crowded though, with only a few groups of people on the tracks. Even without seeing many animals or birds (we could hear them though), there are some amazing trees, the park is free of rubbish and it's a very calming and enjoyable walk. Cost 650 rupee and you get a leaflet/map.

This is a bit isolated and not many people visit. But if walking in a forest is something you enjoy, then do spend half a day here. A local tuk tuk can drop you here. While returning you have a short walk to get transportation. Carry lots of water and some snacks as there is no food available. Ensure you have thick socks and good footwear, there are leeches lurking around. And an umbrella would be handy as it rains sometimes.

This was actually my favourite place in Kandy. There was hardly anyone there, it was peaceful and teeming with wildlife. We saw baboons, wild boar, a snake, fish, birds and my friend swears he saw a crocodile! Great place for a leisurely walk to get out of the hustle and bustle and away from the coach loads of tourists.
If you have few days in Kandy, worth to see, it is a nice walk, there might be some leaches on the way

The Sanctuary is a wonderful place - wild vegetation and lots of animals. We saw monkeys, owls and deers. However, I strongly suggest to wear sneakers because of leeches, that you can find especially on the longer walks. The Lovers walk is very easy and charming.

The sanctuary is rich with unique flora and fauna. It is good for a school trip and as well as for an university trip. Luckily could visit the Maithri Lena which is a Buddhist monk spends his life with the horrible sounds of nature. He is old and we should respect him for his effort. N.B. This place is not for couples and and this is a family or friends entry place.

Loved this place. Could walk around and forget that you're in a bustling city. Nice and cool - shaded by trees. Saw monkeys, scorpions and some amazing tree formations. Only takes an hour or so if you don't do the full loop so easy to find the time!!

We did a big tour around the park and heared a lot of birds, but we didn't see any because we were not properly equipped. Be sure to put on you leech socks. The park is beautiful and there is a wide variety of plants.

We had a wonderful time walking in this sanctuary. They had maps and directions in place and we could walk on our own without the need of guides. Being birdwatchers, we could spot many bird species. We visited twice as we enjoyed the trek. Very calm place with sounds of birds chirping.

this is a cool, small beautiful Jungle. A lot of magestic trees and huge vines are there. But you have to be very careful from leaches. This is a good place for a bird watching too. There is a little lake in the middle of the jungle. Ideal place for a picnic. It want take much time to go round.

Rich in bio diversity. Rich in flora and fauna. Several foot paths within the sanctuary. Large number of insects,small animals and mammals live there. There is a large pool with many varieties of fish. Strol around with a camera to relieve stress.
This is also a beautiful place . It was a royal forest reserve where no one was allowed to go . It feels nice walking around this place and learn the history.

A place you must visit.. Foreigners Rs. 650/- p.p.. Local Rs. 30/- p.p.. Snacks not allowed to bring in. Only a bottle of water. Cycling is permitted (should bring your own). Vehicles not allowed. Walk about 5 km into the jungle. No need to afraid. Totally safe place. No harm from animals or from people. Do not go away from the track. Take a photo of the map on the entrance board before entering the jungle.

It was a nice place close to the kandy city. You may bring umbrella, water bottle and some snacks while you are visiting there. Ask for the map from the counter and you can follow the numbers given for each location.

Entrance price seems a little steep but this area has been conserved for nature since the 19th century. If you can get over that cost you'll probably see a load of trees, some lizards, a whole bunch of monkeys and maybe a deer or two. Not to mention the birds and the views over Kandy. A pleasant way to kill an hour or two and get away from the city. There's an easy 3km trail to follow.

A recurring theme in Sri Lanka is that there are always 2 prices for everything. The cost for tourists can be 4x or 5x more expensive, here is no different. It's 650 for a tourist a 30 rupees for a local. There is no reason to even have an entrance fee. Save your money and avoid! (Walk around the lake instead)

The sun is blocked by the tall, tall trees, and the birds are chirping to each other. Enjoy the walk, the many trails, the calm nature and seeing the different animals! You won't want to miss this place. We saw a snake, some monkeys, birds, butterflies, etc. such a lovely afternoon!!! Definitely recommend

This sanctuary is a beautiful place to visit in kandy. If u r so tired with the kandy crowd and need a place to rest or make you calm, this is the best place. Walking distance from kandy town. Can see many birds in there.  There is a beautiful kandy view point. If u can find bicycles ,there is a bicycle root in the sanctuary and you can have so much fun riding through the jungle.

Although very close to the town even the tuktuk driver did not know where this was and had to ask directions!  Very little visited this is a lovely peaceful place with abundant birdlife and mammals.  Best time to go is the morning.  The easy to follow trails - although the provided map is useful - are mostly shaded and open out every so often giving splendid views of the countryside and over Kandy.

This really is a sanctuary in the middle of the city. The old Royal Gardens and now a Nature Reserve and Forest is a haven from the hustle and bustle of central Kandy. Well worth a visit. See if you can find the hermit monk living in a cave.

Entrance fee Rs 650 - Open 6 am to 6 pm If you're not fond of noisy cities or need a nature break this is the place to head for. I went there to birdwatch once in the late afternoon and again early the following morning. Had a fantastic time and saw many many exotic birds and other animals. No evidence of courting couples along Lovers Walk, I pretty much had the place to myself. There is also a great view point overlooking Kandy & it's lake from the hills above. Apart from the lovely vista the area was abundant with birdlife and kept me enthralled for a few hours. The forest was very dry and no leeches were about, If you want to go in earlier than 6pm, speak to the front gate person the day before and they will alert the guard to sell you the entrance ticket. I found there was plenty of birding outside and up to the gate to keep me busy until they opened. Staff were very friendly and helpful. Only negative was they had run out of maps. You can also organise for a guide (tip) to take you around and show you interesting things you might otherwise walk past.
We enjoyed our visit to the sanctuary, it is very peaceful and not at all crowded. close to the city and easy to find, allow a couple of hours and take drinks there is no where to buy food or drink.
Good place to visit, to walk . Just walking distance from Kandy City to Udawatta Kale. It has many kinds of birds and more things for the nature lovers.

You quickly feel you are away from the city and you can get a very pleasant walk in. Leeches supposedly are a problem - but I think Ok when it's dry. Saw pigs and barking deer and macaques - hoping to see birds but probably need early morning trip for them.

Udawattekele Sanctuary is a great place to have relaxing walk. It has tall trees, beutiful small lake at the middle of the forest. there is an Buddhist monastery (Thapowanaya temple)  at the entrance of the forest. there is a place to the south of the small lake that you could see the Kandy town from the top. also this within the walking distance from the Kandy city. 20 minutes walk

We had a lovely walk here. it was very easy and so quiet! You get to see monkeys, birds and wonderful view of kandy at a special point. It is really nice to have this wonderful park in the city of kandy. We recommend everybody to come and experience it!

One of my favorite places in Kandy. Minutes away from the Kandy town, its an amazing place for a quiet stroll. If you start early you will get to see some bird life, few turtles in the lake at the entrance, few Deer and you will not miss the Monkeys.

This park is just incredible. The rangers at the front who sell tickets are scammers through. The entrance fee is 650 rupees. So I counted out 6 x 100 rupee notes and one 50 rupee note. They said ok and gave me a map (no ticket) but just 30 seconds after walking off they called me back and said that I was short 100 rupees. While my back was turned they pocketed one of the 100 rupee notes leaving only 5 on the counter. It was pointless to argue so I just handed over one more. Despite this the sanctuary is beautiful and well worth a visit. It's 250 acres just behind the Temple of the Tooth. Head west from the Temple up the street with the Pizza Hut and the Queen hotel on the corner. Go about 400m and turn right at the first set of traffic lights. Follow the winding road up the hill (easily walkable). The rainforest is pristine as it has been preserved by the Kings since the 1200s. The walking trails are well marked and easy. There are troops of monkeys which show no interest in people and which, unlike elsewhere in SE Asia are not aggressive and just walk calmly past you as if you're not there.  It's amazing to walk past a whole family of monkeys so close (within a metre) while they mind their own business, carrying their babies and grooming each other with none of the aggressive behaviour you usually see in monkeys that live this close to humans. In a 2 hour visit I also saw wild boar and tiny deer. It's so peaceful and lovely and incredible to think it's an easy 20 min walk from Kandy city. Just closely watch what you pay as you go in!
We went on a long walk through the forest. Not many people there so it was peaceful . There is a lake there too. A beautiful p[lace not far from Kandy.

This is a nice place to have som quiet time after experiencing the city of Kandy. There is a lot of different threes, and we also saw monkeys, wild boar, deer and a lot of birds during our walk. A nice and calm forest.

As said in other reviews, this place is a nice getaway from the city. Most people took tuk tuk to entrance, but it's easy enough to hike (go west of tooth temple, not east). Unlike a lot of reviews with leeches, we didn't encounter any, and we did every trail.  Perhaps these are more a problem in rainy season?

Took our lunch & spent a few hours walking round, talking to like minded people. Lovely to be away from the city noise & dirt. When we arrived we were greeted by the monkeys, inside there are more monkeys, deer, wild boar, lizards snakes & lovely birds & butterflies. Well worth the visit. ,
very nice place close to Kandy for a peaceful walk in the woods. we saw no wildlife, but also none of the leeches other have complained about

Why do so few people visit here? It's right next to the city and offers a great experience - see monkeys close up at the entrance, enjoy the twisted vines of the jungle as you walk through listening to the birds. Easy walking in the shade, a good track and you're almost alone. Try it out.

If you are quiet and patient, you might have e few sights of animals (apes, different birds, deer..) And if you are not careful you might have some other encounters - not so desirable - with LEECHES on wet days. Be careful, wear good shoes and spray your lower legs and feet
Lovely walk, couldn't believe this was in a city. Beware of leeches though - we had lots stuck to our shoes!
Magnificent, this country has so many shrines and places of antiquity to visit, all well worth it. We visited again last year and it was good to go over old and new ground.

After the full-on Kandy city experience, this place is somewhere to calm you down. Not a long walk from the city centre but if it's too hot take a tuktuk, it,s not far. Just a gentle ramble in beautiful surroundings - with lots of monkeys! Also very good for birdwatching.
good for hikes, can see the entire kandy city if you reach the top of the sanctuary, climbing up in the morning and spending the day there  will be fun

It's a beautiful forest near Kandy city centre. We saw a deer, monkeys, a boar and a lot of insects. Entrance fee is 650 rs pp.  At the end, we took the wrong path with a lot of leeches! Best to bring some mosquito spray to spray on the leeches and take attention to take the correct route. Be aware of groups with young boys. They slap you on the butt if you are a woman. We were here on a Sunday, so maybe it's better to go on a weekday as they are at school. We told the caretaker and he was really helpful.

a little forest at the outskirts of the city centre. A great place to visit f you are interested in horticulture and bird watching. Many other small rare creatures. I suggest to stay still for thirty minuets and listen to the combination of birds, and creatures singing. I made a recording of the sounds here.

Spent a lovely 2 to 3 hours slowly walking around this wildlife area. It was quiet and peaceful, yet is only a kilometre (if that) from Kandy town centre. Lots of monkeys - bonnet macaques and turtles in the large pond. We were also lucky enough to see an owl. From the edge of the sanctuary, there are beautiful views over the town and Kandy lake.

Cheapest and best way to relax and do a bit of excersise in kandy. Amazes me how many people skip this when they come to Kandy, its so close to the centre of town yet once inside you wouldnt know it as its so quiet and peaceful. Highly recommend

Walking distance from anywhere in Kandy. Untouched forest. Many places to rest. food available, although they advice not to feed the local wild life. There is a Lake in the middle, peaceful majestic. walkways crisscross many different type of vegetation.  ideal for a romantic getaway. Last visit 2007

if you are able to visit this sanctuary you will be amaze. this place is located near to Kandy city and this place has a great history. if you are lucky enough, you will be able to get some great information about this sanctuary and ancient Kandy kingdom from one of the local person lives around here.

Udawattekele is an area of natural forest on the very doorstep of Kandy city.  I visited it with my 14 year old daughter at 06.00 in the morning and we had the whole place pretty much to ourselves - we stayed for around 4 hours.  You get given a map and suggested itinerary at the entrance and the very clear paths make it just about impossible to get lost. We saw deer, wild boar and the inevitable monkeys along with a variety of birds and insects (but absolutely no leeches!).  But the sheer variety of vegetation is enough to make it worth going it itself.
Superb little forest - just above the Temple of the Tooth. Take a picnic lunch and lots of water and just spend an afternoon or morning wondering around. Lots of birds, butterflies etc

We lived close by and spent most of out childhood play time in this forest, before they cordoned it off. I have visited this place recently with some of my foreign guests and sadly it is nothing much and the forest has thinned out and not what it used to be. Even the fauna and flora has decreased. I see it easier to spot birds, reptiles etc in my home that here. Anthem the rate for foreigners is unreasonably high compared to what is there to see now.

Nice and relaxing walk in kandy to get away from the hustle and bustle. We walked around for about 2 hours, could spend longer in there or be done a bit quicker though. We did get some leeches on us so might be best to wear long pants and tuck them into socks. Maps also arnt the clearest but isnt too hard to find your way. 700 rupes to enter but as it is a conservation area it goes to a goos cause

Really enjoyed our time walking around this beautiful forest, if you're keen for peace and quiet out of hectic Kandy then definitely come here. We did however get a bit lost due to the maps not being very informative. We made our way down a not so well trotted path and got bitten by a few leeches. Come prepared incase you happen to get lost or want to explore other trails, tuck your pants into your socks! The entrance price is a bit steep at 700 rupees per person, but not uncommon for Sri Lanka

This is on all levels the best thing about Kandy. The city is intolerably noisy and busy, which I get it, can be charming, but nothing beats the beauty of getting lost in these gardens. And by gardens I mean a forest. We walked around for 2 hours before making it back to the exit. Unfortunately we didn't see any animals but the scenery was just incredible.

For simply walking around in nature, the fee of Rs600 is too high, especially since you hardly get to see anything except butterflies and some monkeys. The place is too close to traffic and that could be one reason for the low wildlife count. We saw a lot more bird species around the Kandy Lake compared to Udawattekele Sanctuary.
One of its kind in Asian, this is a uniquely preserved nature forest and you can spend the whole day in this nature forest, it is so relaxing. Entry tickets apply but less than $20.00.
Beautiful and quiet escape from the noise and chaos of Kandy City.  Just watch out for the leeches and wild boar!

It is calming to walk along the dirt trails through the forest. The screeching of the crickets some times gives you the creeps. But it gives you the kind of experience in a deep jungle. I personally loved it. Wonderful place for nature lovers to spend time walking and talking . Not much of an attraction otherwise.

Beautiful forest pretty much inside the city. A mini sinharaja. What I would have wished was a guide that tells me more about the plants and animals living there, they did not offer unfortunately. The lady at the entrance says she has no change but actially she has ;)
Amazing view full of nature at it's best and not polluted, and exceptionally breath taking. Any one would enjoy this!
Cool and Calm place to relax your mind. Very beautiful. Its is really nice on early morning and you can see the sun rise through trees and mountains....
This is a very calm place which is situated near the Kandy City. It is a calm and Quiet place which is suitable for those who like to do meditation.

From the busy city of Kandy, you can't imagine this type of quite beautiful forest is situated there. This is man-made forest made by king Rajasinghe for his palace wood requirement of kitchen and other things.. Now it's a huge forest.. Very quiet and calm place.. You need atleast 4 to 5 hours to explore full jungle..

That forest is very attractive.no need to spend  big amount..very peaceful THIS  PLACE IS INTERESTING  ONLY FOR NATURAL LOVERS. There are lot of  road ways long distance to walk.If you need you can use bicycle . There are 3 forest monestries  in side the forest .buddist  monks are maditating Don't disturb them TRY TO KEEP UP  SILENT BACKGROUND.

So close to bustling Kandy city, it is difficult to imagine one can find such a beautiful quiet forest area to enjoy nature and interesting walking tracks! This forest is reportedly over 200 years now, and feels a special place of history. I would suggest two to three hours be allowed so that one can truly enjoy the serenity of the forest, such a relief from the noise and business of the town. Only downside are the leeches, of whoch there appear to be a multitude! Mostly if venturing off the paths, however. Recently I am shocked to hear that it is being proposed to cut a bypass road through this beauiful, historic, nature reserve and forest!!! I certainly hope this never happens! We need to preserve every patch of forest on the planet, no matter how small! My advice...go visit this patch of paradise before it perhaps disappears! Have they also considered that the revenue from visitors fees will also be lost?
It was an amazing walk even tought we got supprised by some wild boar and chased by monkeys - dont bring any food :D

Our walk around the sanctuary was nice, nothing extraordinary. There were lots of monkeys which at first excited me greatly, until I realised there are monkeys everywhere in Sri Lanka, and I didn't have to pay to see them. We didn't see anyone other than park rangers on the walk which was lovely and relaxing, but again confused as to what we were paying for. At the end of the walk we found ourself having to exit the reserve through a dodgy area, we ended up on a back road behind a temple scrambling over plants. According to the map, this was the exit. At the bottom there was a chained up elephant which left me in tears, he looked so sad and badly treated. Overall we had a nice walk in the sanctuary but wouldn't recommend it especially with the price tag.

We enjoyed our walk in the forest. It was nice to get out of town. We didn't see any monkeys and got caught in a downpour, but we saw a few nice birds, and enjoyed looking at the luxuriant vegetation. Watch out for the leeches though.

Only came across 2 groups of people in the 90 minutes that we spent there. Some of the signs are not so clear so we wasted a bit of time. Saw one deer and a lot of monkeys. It is just a forest but it nice given the high energy level of Kandy.

Udawatta kale Sanctuary is a Green wet forest boudaring to Sri Dalandaa Maaligaawa Kandy. 365 day green leaved thick forest with huge trees old more than hundreds of years. flora and fona Inheritant to Sri Lanka can be found in their natural habitat here. Ideal place for environmental researchers and who love the nature!.
A cozy walk in a circle for about 1.5 hours.  Not many sites and the signs along the route are not so detailed and informative.  We even could not find the German caves.  Can skip for limieted time.

This forest is pretty easy to navigate without a guide, using the map given out at the entrance. Even if you do lose your way, you can't go too wrong and you'll inevitably find your way back to the entrance. The forest is really lovely and there's a lot of wildlife. We saw lots of monkeys as well as wild boar, deer, a snake and some nice birds. A great way to spend a couple of hours and also a good way to avoid the heat of the sun.

Easy walking distance from Kandy city center. Beautiful forest with monkeys, birds and probably other animals (that we didn't see). So nice to get away from the sun (the trees give shade) and city for a while. Also good walking tracks and a nice view point with a great view of Kandy Lake.
A beautiful and Fantastic place to see lots of wildlife ..Loved the hike into this sanctuary, we saw monkeys and birds. A must visit place.

A lovely rain forest with a huge "pus wela", which covers 2 acres and is over 200 years old. Mind the many leeches, which are all over the place after rain. Although leeches are not dangerous, their bites hurt, so don't wear sandals! We saw monkeys, a boar and many birds.

The entrance fee is OK (650 Rps per person) and you get a map. The map is fine, but we couldn't find some of the caves, which are indicated on the map and the signposts in the park. We are birdwatchers, so we walk very slowly, listening for every sound and looking for every movement in the trees or in the understory. Although the sanctuary is on the edge of Kandy, you here the sounds of the city all the time and a few times a car was driving on the main track. We liked the big group of macaques, which are hanging around the entrance area. We liked the walk and the sanctuary, but except for some spots with Giant Bamboo or beautiful vines it felt like an ordinary forest. That's why we give 3*.

I don't know how many people choose this place as their another attraction in Kandy, but this is a very good place to travel for nature lover. You wont feel that you were so close to Kandy city center.

As a "birdie" I had expected this to be a rich source of interest, but it is composed almost entirely of forest, and viewable birds were at a distinct premium!  There were very few other visitors, and we all seemed to be outnumbered by soldiers in combat gear with AK47s.  They were very friendly, but their presence was a bit unnerving! Then there were the persistent leaches that went for my legs after a brief rain shower.  All very entertaining, but not quite what I'd expected!

we had an advanture when we were there. we  walked slowly in this forest. suddenly our leader sayed to us "do not stop and run  please run". we can not see anything or any animal but while we were runing he explained some worms with ability to seek your blood are here and if you stay and stop any where they attack you, if any person like to know what happen for us please contact with my email address:  hkhosrojerdi@gmail.com

The forrest was absolutely stunning. It quiet and serene however, the further you climb, the more leeches you are likely to encounter. We were unaware of this and as such we wore open shoes. I would recommend closed footwear and tight pants and perhaps, some repellant. Other than this very minor complaint, the Udawattekele Sanctuary is beautiful and the scenery is stunning.
After having travelled all the way to Kandy we were not granted permission to enter, was a terrible experience.

Having to pay the steep entrance fees along with the safari charges and guide tips - certainly not worth just to see few elephants. Safari in some other national parks around the world are far far better. Just another commercial establishment like the many others in Srilanka.

I was completely alone and in 20 minutes walk from Kandy center I felt like I was in a real jungle/forest with monkeys swinging around and peace in the air. Tip: Watch out for leeches. Little ones that will sneakily to your shoe and then to your ankle :)  Don't be scared of that. Go check it out for some fresh air, a GREAT view of Kandy at point E (I think) on the map, and a chance to watch monkeys in their habit and possible little deer that cruise through there.

The Forest is located with in the city and no one would assume a natural, tropical forest to be located in once a Capital City. A walk through the forest will make you close to the nature. You can observe many flora and fauna. The forest is well preserved and protected and dropping litter and plastic is prohibited. Be a bit careful, if you step away (or when set foot on foliage) from the provided trails as there are serpents in abundance. I have been here many many times. Though I caution here, it is very safe.
This forest is quite dense and it gives a break from the buzz in Kandy. We saw wild boars, an owl, a snake and many birds.
Nice and peaceful walk in a forest. You can see many animals like monkeys, agamas, etc. You will get a map at entrance. You need about 2 hours for it.

A breath of fresh air (so to speak in the heat) after the center of Kandy. A beautiful forest with one side a beautiful view of the city but quite noisy as close to the road. On the other you are surrounded by nature with very few visitors, damage some cars or motorcycles go through some trails. Another bad point, the plan is anything but clear to find some points of view. Anyway we enjoyed the meet monkeys, iguanas, snakes and wild boars !!

Udawattekele forest is close to the centre of KANDY and very easy to reach by tuctuc taxi. There are views toward the city  and kandy lake . Easy broad paths that lead through the tropical forest around the pond. A lot of rainforest birds can be heard and spiders and monkeys can be seen. recommended.

After three days hill walking in the tea plantation of Sri Lanka at 3000mtrs we decided to have a rest day today in Kandy. That lasted till 12noon when the hotel manager suggested that we go to the rain forest for a walk. One tuk tuk later, We headed in with our map and local emergence phone, provided by the hotel. At first it was wonderful, huge trees covered in giant vines with monkeys and snakes all over the place. Ants and millepedes the size of your largest finger. Confidently guiding my family with the map i directed them deeper and deeper into the rain forest. The canopy was so dense that it made the forest floor dark. We stopped for a drink then I felt it! I though it was an ant bite, sharpe and pin point pain. I looked down and nearly dropped with the shock. There were five or six leeches on my leg and foot. Bear Grills I am not, I flicked them off and sprinted forward hoping to leave them behind us, the kids followed in panic as there father led the way. My Wife calm and collected walked along, laughing until she too realised that if you stood still the leeches were all over you. I looked down at the ground and the forest floor was alive with leeches. Every two or three inches there was a leech stretching it's neck upward, swaying hoping to find some pale Irish skin. We ran for 3 to 4km through deep jungle as the leeches could not latch on when you ran. In the panic and noise of us all getting eaten alive I realised that i missed jogging. This was fun, soft ground, great scenery and laughs (fear). Who knew, all I missed was the correct motivation. I wondered if they used leeches on usain bolt, no? Should have, they work. Well after a 30min run we got back to the path and onto civilisation. My 10yr old son looked up at me and said "Dad you have three leeches on your face" f€&@....... I shouted. I had read the map backwards and led us all into the jungle and off trail. Sorry guys! Two hours later in a super market I found the last leech in my runner, full and bloated. Kids want to move back to Eire!

I took a recording kit and spent a good half a day visiting this place, which is located in a forest within the city. the birds insects and other creatures including monkeys produce a cocktail of sound which is fascinating and amazing to listen too.
Great opportunity to get up close to an elephant, be prepared though the handlers will expect paying, but well worth the 1000 rupees I paid, excellent experience.

A beautiful forest, amazing vines, trees, Dorian fruit trees  Nice view over kandy,. Saw very little wildlife. husband attracted a couple of leeches, rest of us were fine. Cost almost £10 for a family of 4 which I think is too much.  I know we need to pay to preserve such lovely areas, but I feel Sri Lanka is cashing in too much. Visit if you have some spare time, makes a pleasant escape from the bustle of kandy.

I'll preface this by saying I should have done my research beforehand... My fiancé and I came here during wet season and our tuk tuk driver joked that he and his wife avoid it in the wet season due to leaches. We were swearing thongs and sandals respectively - mistake! There were leaches everywhere we went and the tracks are really poorly sign posted. As a result, we took a wrong turn and found ourselves face-to-face with a huge snake. With our path blocked, we detoured and came face-to-face with a wild boar. After thankfully finding some other tourists in a similar boat (i.e lost), we managed to make our way out thanks to Google maps 2 hours after we started. While I can appreciated the beauty of the place, it was a pretty scary experience. Be prepared!

If it hasn't rained a day or two before you visit this gem of a forest in the middle of Kandy, you are going to be in your imagined 7th heaven! Go to the pool where many a King beheaded his mistresses.

We enjoyed the walk. Nothing special.  Couldn't understand why it was so expensive (almost 2000 lkr) for 2 adults and 2 kids. Harldy anyone visits the place because the price is relatively expensive.  You can enjoy a place in the UK (Brecon Beacons) for zero cost and its much more spectacular with its waterfalls and lush hills. So, no, sorry to say, but poor value for an otherwise attractive walk.
I really should have listened to past reviewers.  There are serious leaches.  I ended up trail running by the end, which I never do.  Do not go here.  It was awful!

The Sinharaja Rain Forest is spectacular. We saw so many endemic birds, snakes and plants to Sri Lanka. We also got to tick off the Sri Lankan Blue Magpie and Sri Lankan Frogmouth from our "to see" list, which was extremely exciting.

Approached from the far end of town this park has excellent walking paths, is naturally made up of differing types of flora and is quite beautiful Do take plenty of water and some food if planning to stay for a while, Well maintained routes make walking easy and occasional, completely unobtrusive signage means that you do not get lost. tremendous specimens of local forest trees and plants, with amazing flowers and lianas. Well worth a visit and so cool and clean. A must do in Kandy. Exiting from the rear entrance, close to the Kandy Lake view point, will bring you out very close to Nature Walk Hotel, as a guide.

it was nice, what can you say, the elephants were rodden bareback to save chaffing, but my driver insisted we come here instead of the orphanage, I thought a mistake, if I did it again I would do both...beware these are all pricy exercises.

this beautiful little forest is located within the city yet is a true forest with lots of birds and insects giving it a calm feel. an afternoon sroll under the large canopy and shrubs was an amazing feeling before luch.

Its a jungle walk with sound of nature all around..chirping of birds, a myna's song, woodpeckers' call, owl's gaze, wild flowers, old tree roots winding all around and sun rays peeking from the lush green thick mane of the trees! kids loved it!!

Do your self a favour and take a threewheeler around 6AM to the Royal Forest Park entrance. For 650 LKR (locals pay 30 rupees) you enter the quietest easy-to-access tropical forest just a stone-throw away from the overcrowded Kandy town center. After entering the forest take a left-left to follow the anti-clockwise route until you eventually reach a visitor's center (one hour walk). From there, continue 100m to exit the park left-ish towards the Kandy lake side and you are back into the city. Do not expect too much birds but clean air and quietness are kind of priceless too. Walking paths are well maintained so buggy's can be taken there (only in dry season). The reason that you can't bring any food into the park is that Sri Lankans don't understand the concept of not throwing anything away ... Only recommendation I could make is to let people enter on the other side as well. Why isn't this allowed??

It was a pleasant surprise to be given a map when we paid our entrance fee to the sanctuary.  So often in Sri Lanka we have found that we have had to pay high entrance fees, then no map.  We went early, in order to enjoy the birdlife.  It was a very pleasant, slow two hour walk, as we tried to identify the wide variety of birdcalls we heard.  This was a struggle, as the sanctuary is well wooded and the birds quite elusive.  We identified and photographed a few, also saw a family of wild boar, a troop of monkeys and a deer.  Highlights for us were spotting Lesser Goldenback and Crimsonbacked Goldenbacks (woodpeckers) and seeing a Lesser Hill Mynah on its nest in a hole in a tree. The walk is very well signposted with a number of routes.  We only did the main circuit, which is about 3km.  Very quiet, very peaceful.

Awesome tropical nature with great big trees, lake, hills, ravines to getaway from the stresses of commercial modern life.   Excellent quiet place to meditate and silence the mind listening to the chirping birds, innocent bunches of monkeys with cool hair cuts, porcupines and wild geese.   The hike is long enough to spend the entire day if one carries a picnic lunch, don't bother to carry water as the brooks are full of fresh flowing water.  Recommended for those seeking solitude, meditation and to still the mind.

A lovely area of forest sits on the hill above Kandy.  So peaceful and varied with many species of the trees and other plants which grow in the Hill Country.  Huge spiral lianas wind up into the canopy in places and birdsong fills the air. It is a bit difficult to match the map on your ticket to the paths and signs at junctions in the forest add to the unclear advice you get from the bored person who issues the entrance tickets. But this is an unpolluted oasis above the city and one well worth a visit - not to be missed.

Great little walk round the loop path of the Sanctuary through some awe inspiring trees and vines. We saw very little wildlife except for a brief hint of a deer and possible turtle in the pond, but the leaches were out in force in the wet and mud, so ensure you have closed shoes - my flipflops were useless!

we went after a lot of rain intop this rain forest. Despite the easy to walk paths being wide and free of vegetation, little leeches found us. Take a bar of soap to get them off-better still rub ankles with soap before start. Im sure if dry theyd not be a problem and wed have enjoyed it !. We saw no birds

Saw really incredible Liane plants, they look like the huge chains of ship anchors, amazing how they grow up into the air, some really high, across the paths. Can only imagine they grew over some saplings and then waited a couple of hundred years for the tree to grow and carry them up into the air. Truely asonishing to see it for the first time.
If you ever have a chance of coming to Kandy on a holiday do not go without visiting the Udawattekele forest which is one of the really beautiful palaces in Kandy

I had a good weather when I ventured here. I didn't really get leeches or was sunburnt. The path was a bit confusing especially if you follow the map so it';s better to ask the person at the gate about it first. It's a refuge from the noise of the city.

very nice stroll that gives you a feeling of nature while still being in the city. Nice great trees, thick jungle, you can peer at specific animals at some point : lizards, snakes, butterflies. It is well maintained with good pathways with clear indications so giving a chance to walk around for everyone. those who want more of an adventure feeling can go on smaller paths. Inside the park you have buddhist retreat places. Some great viewpoints to observe from a higher perspective the Kandy valley and surrounding mountains.

Udawattekelle brings back many memories to me each time I walk in its paths. As a school boy I used to come here to study at times. When we studied Botany our class mates & lecturers came here for practical lessons. It was just jumping over the college fens & we were in Udawattekelle. History states that there are mystical powers at Udawattekelle. In folklore It is stated that the oppressed/weak are strengthened & turn tables on the predator in this sanctuary. I found a office in the middle of the sanctuary that has books on Udawattekelle at a nominal fee.   I also found a book written by Dr. Nihal Karuanaratne on Udawattekele which is not in print now(only 1 edition had been printed in 1986). Only a few libraries have this book which talks extensively about this sanctuary. Photographers be at the lake by 05.30 am. The best months for this are Nov - February. Take a strong tripod & a shutter delay timer. The view from the other end of the  sanctuary overlooking the lake / above the Dalada maligawa is spectacular in the evenings. Take some Siddalepa balm as there are leaches. Apply it on your feet & hems of trousers , Sides of shoes before you enter. Never allow children under 12 years alone. Never try to wander alone. Never feed the monkeys or even encourage them near you. There are 2 groups of monkeys. The Udawattekelle gang & the Aruppola/Lewella gang. Udawattekelle is one of their meeting places. Never get close when they clash. Read their body language & retreat as fast as possible. I have seen these 2 gangs of monkeys clash for many years. Never show any sign of fruit, biscuits, bread, cakes, savories or sweets. They have got used to eating all these for many years. They approach you without fear & grab the food from you. So don't eat in their presence. Report any misbehavior  of any one. That includes shouting loud. This is a place of silence. One must only take photographs & leave only your footprints. This sanctuary is the center of the ecology system in Kandy & therefore it should be preserved. It was saddening to see names & slang cut into the giant bamboo trees around the lake at Udawattekelle. I hope that all would enjoy all what I have in the past.

Enjoyed this solace in the town. We had a troop of monkeys literally cross our path. I don't think they realised we were there. They were doing something with the toilets, I don't know what exactly was happening but it is an area they need to improve on.

Udawatta kele is a preserved forest sanctuary, gazetted by the government many years ago. The forest is full of thick vegetation where you are free to have a beautiful trek through it. Over looking , you can observe the beautiful range of Dumbara hills and the blue hills of the  famous Knuckles range far out. The uniqueness is that it is located just above the city of Kandy and spreads along the river Mahaveli and curved inland of few kilometers. Wild bow, deer, mongoose, numerous serpents and a wide variety of birds are inhabitants of this valuable green stretch of land, so closer to a busy town. If you have time to relax a bit and enjoy the tranquility , keeping away your stress of being in concrete jungles ( busy towns) this would be an ideal location.

Fantastic place to see lots of wildlife right next to the city centre. We saw monkeys, deer, lizards, turtles in their natural habitat, it was amazing! We normally do things quickly but took a good couple of hours to walk around. Great place to visit although beware for leeches! Even though we'd read about them and covered up with closed shoes and long trousers, my husband still managed to get a bite from one, only noticed a few hours later when he took his jeans off and his leg was pouring of blood!

It is also known as the forbidden forest of the kings of Kandy. A great place to hike for a couple of hours enjoying he nature and viewing some bird life. With some luck you might see wild boar, Money's, Hare, Squirrels, Porcupines, and seven some reptiles, Water monitors, Lizards, Tortise and a variety of birds,. The pond in the heart of the jungle is believed to be the the place where queens in the pas bathed and used as their player garden. The brown fish owl is a famous sighting in the forest though you have to spend a little Ike to spot it and in one visit you might not see all above... Would highly recommend this visit I anyone who has 1-2 hours o spare whilst in Kandy. During the wet season just be cautious about the leeches.

Love the tranquility. U become one with nature when u enter this place. Do not expect to see many wild animals except for birds and occasional rodents and cold blooded creatures! Truly an awesome place where time stops!!!

The nature is extremely good for lives as its very rich with surrounded fresh air and water.Forestry the natural atmosphere is realy worth than its beauti,since among the very rear and extraodinery places in the world where the nature can be enjoyed deep in it.no freezing or shivering in any climetic condition through out the year. lal de silva
An amazing area of untouched tropical jungle within walking distance of the city. Don't go off-track - there's leeches, as we quickly found out! Lots of wildlife and amazing vegetation.

This is a great hike - beautiful country, paths are good and plenty of monkeys. We heard a lot of birds but didnt see too many so probably best to go early morning if you can. We took about 2 hours but you could do it in an hour if you didnt have lots of time. But there are small leaches so wear shoes, socks and long pants - and after check your legs. I got back to the hotel and was lying around on the bed and noticed blood everywhere!

the scenry is just beautiful: a rainforest not far outside of Kandy - huge trees, some monkeys, dense vegetation, nice views of Kandy - a little information centre - just nice to walk. we were there in the rainy season, and then the leeches are obviously very active - unfortunatly we got lost - and so took a tiny path, the rain started - and as soon we stopped to get orientation, leeches crawled up your shoes - so many that we couldn't avoid bites. I think if we'd stayed on the swept paths there would have been less risk - so it was partly our fault of course

Loved the hike into this sanctuary - we saw snakes and monkeys and a lot of bird life.  We`d have done more hiking here were it not for the leeches - you definitely want to wear close-toed shoes here.

This is a great place to escape the bustle of Kandy, but is really close - maybe 20 mins walk from Temple of the Tooth. Verdant, green, tropical. Several walks are possible so you can walk for hours if you like. Wildlife is varied but watch out for leeches - spray or cover feet and legs! Recommended for anyone who likes nature.

When I visited Udawattakelle Sanctuary for the first time I was really amazed by the amount of things to see in there. I visited a hermitage which prohibited entrance since the monks need absolute privacy. There was a "Sakman Maluwa" which is a place where the monks meditate while walking. There were some ancient caves inside the sanctuary as well. The government had recently launched a cycling route inside the sanctuary, but unfortunately the cycles were not there at that time for hire. We were told that it would take another couple of days to get there.

After checking out the Temple of the Tooth and other attractions in Kandy itself, we hired a tuktuk to the Udawattekele Sanctuary. It was very nice to escape from the crowd and the heath of the city, and take a walk under the treas. However, we were often disturbed by cars passing by! It is a bit overpriced, but a nice change, when you miss nature in the city.

Udawatta Kele Sanctuary, often spelled as Udawattakele, is a historic forest reserve on a hill-ridge in the city of Kandy. During the days of the Kandyan Kingdom Udawatta Kele was known as "Uda Wasala Watta" in Sinhalese meaning, "the garden situated above the royal palace". The sanctuary is famous for its extensive avifauna. The reserve also contains a great variety of plant species, especially lianas, shrubs and small trees. There are several giant lianas. Many of small and medium size mammals that inhabit Sri Lanka can be seen here. Several kinds of snakes and other reptiles might also be seen. Udawatta Kele was designated as a forest reserve in 1856, and it became a sanctuary in 1938. The Sri Lanka Forest Department has two offices in the reserve, one of which (i.e. the one located at the southeastern entrance) has a nature education centre with a display of pictures, posters, stuffed animals, etc. Being easily accessible and containing a great variety of flora and fauna the forest has a great educational and recreational value. Groups of school children and students regularly visit the forest and the education centre. The forest is also popular with foreign tourists, especially bird watchers. The forest is also of religious importance as there are three Buddhist meditation hermitages and three rock shelter dwellings for Buddhist monk hermits. It has been recorded that the Brahmin called Senkanda, from whose name the city's original name Senkandagalapura derives, lived in a cave in this forest. The rock-shelter or cave now known as the Senkandagala-lena is located on the slope above the temple of the tooth and can be visited. The legend says the brahmin brought a sapling of Jaya Siri Maha Bodhi here and planted it in the present day site of Natha Devale. It was used as a pleasure garden by the Kandyan kings. The forest was reserved for the Royal family and the pond situated in the forest was used for bathing. The public was restricted from accessing the forest hence the name Thahanci kele (Sinhalese for Forbidden forest). During the colonial era some of the land near the Temple of the Tooth was used to build the Kandy garrison cemetery. In 1834 Governor Horton built a path, Lady Horton's drive, within the forest in remembrance of his wife. Henry W. Cave mentions the trail is about three miles long. Lady McCarthy's drive, Lady Torrington's road, Lady Anderson's road, Gregory path, Russell path, Byrde lane and Lady Gordon’s Drive on which the Trip Advisor listed Kandy Cottage is located  are the other named walks in the forest. Some are abandoned and overgrown now. Udawatta Kele is situated on a hill ridge stretching between the Temple of the Tooth and the Uplands-Aruppola suburbs. The highest point of the ridge (7°17'55.41"N, 80°38'40.04"O) is 635 meters above sea level, and 115 meters above the nearby Kandy Lake. The sanctuary contains three Buddhist forest monasteries i.e. Forest Hermitage, Senanayakaramaya and Tapovanaya, and three cave dwellings for Buddhist monks, i.e. Cittavisuddhi-lena, Maitri-lena and Senkadandagala-lena. The sanctuary also acts as a catchment area for the supply of water to the city of Kandy. The visitors' entrance is located on the western side of the forest, about 15–20 minutes walking from the Temple of the Tooth. Directions: From the Temple of the Tooth, go north along the D.S. Senanayaka Veediya road and after half a kilometer turn right at the post office near the Kandy Municipality, and follow the road up the hill. The entrance is on the right side of the Tapovanaya Monastery. It is only a 700m pleasant walk from the Kandy Cottage if you’re accommodated there. There is parking space for cars and vans near the entrance, and a refreshment stall. The entrance fee for Sri Lankan visitors is Rs. 30,-; the fee for foreign visitors is Rs. 570,-. Sri Lankan visitors have to register and leave their identity card at the entrance. Amorous unmarried couples are not allowed to enter the forest. The shady lovers' walk, which runs along the banks of the royal pond, is the most popular walk. During rainy weather there are many leeches lurking along paths that will attempt to suck blood from the feet and legs of unwary visitors. Mosquito repellent or herbal balms such as Siddhalepa will protect against them. The vegetation of the park comprises dense forest, mostly abandoned plantations and secondary formations. Of the 460 plant species that have been recorded in the forest, 135 are species of tree and 11 are lianas. These include 9 endemic species. The forest features an emergent layer, a canopy and an understory. Because of the dense two upper layers, understory is not present everywhere in the sanctuary, especially in areas with the invasive Peru balsam tree, (Myroxylon balsamum) Mahogany trees, (Swietenia macrophylla) and Devil's Ivy, (see Invasive Species section below). A great variety of species are found in the forest. Some common native tree and shrub species are: Acronychia pedunculata (Sinhalese: "Ankenda"), Artocarpus nobilis ("Wal Del"), Artocarpus heterophyllus ("Kos"), Caryota urens ("Kitul"), Aglaia elaeagnoidea ("Puwanga"), Bombax ceiba ("Katu imbul"), Canarium zeylanicum, Cinnamomum verum ("Kurundu", cinnamon), Ficus virens, Filicium decipiens ("Pihimbiya"), Goniothalamus gardneri, Haldina cordifolia, Hunteria zeylanica, Mallotus tetracoccus, Mesua ferrea ("Na", ”Iron-wood”), Michelia champaca ("Sapu"), Mangifera zeylanica ("Atamba"), Neoclitsea cassia ("Dawul Kurundu”, Wild Cinnamon), Glycosmis sp., Litsea quinqueflora, Micromelum minitum ("Wal Karapuncha"), Pavetta blanda, Psychotria nigra, Vitex pinnata ("Milla") and Walsura gardneri. There are many vine and liana species growing in the Udawattakele forest, most notable is the giant creeper Entada rheedii ("Pus Wel"). Some other species are Anamirta cocculus ("Tittawel”), Diploclisia glaucescens, Hiptage bengalensis, Hypserpa nitida ("Niriwel"), Morinda umbellata ("Kiri-wel"), and Paramignya monophylla. The Udawatta Kele is probably the best place in Sri Lanka for seeing full-grown rattan palms, ''Calamus'' (palm), of which there are at least two species. Some of the climbing palms here are over 25 meters long, growing up and over trees. Elsewhere in Sri Lanka rattan palms are often cut down when young for making rattan, but in the Udawattakele they are well protected. Orchid species, mostly epiphytic, include Cymbidium bicolor, Luisa teretifolia, Polystachya concreta, Thrixspermum pulchellum, Tropidia curculigoides and Vanda testacea. The sanctuary also is home to many species of non-flowering plants, Pteridophytes, such as the large ferns growing on steep banks along the shady road on the eastern side of the hill ridge. The tree species Alstonia macrophylla, introduced from Southeast Asia, is a common pioneer in previously cleared areas but poses no great threat to biodiversity because seeds sprout only in sunny, open areas, and when the trees get large, native shrubs and trees grow beneath them to eventually take their place. Udawatta Kele is a famous birdwatching site. About 80 avifaunal species have been recorded from the sanctuary. The endemic bird species are Layard's Parakeet (Psittacula calthropae), Yellow-fronted Barbet (Megalaima flavifrons), and Brown-capped Babbler Pellorneum fuscocapillus. The rare Three-toed Kingfisher Ceyx erythacus has been observed occasionally. Sri Lanka Myna, Golden-fronted Leafbird, Blue-winged Leafbird, Spotted Dove, Emerald Dove, Tickell's Blue Flycatcher, Crimson-fronted Barbet, Brown-headed Barbet and Black-backed Kingfisher are common in the forest. Red-faced Malkoha and Kashmir Flycatcher are two birds listed as threatened that can be found in Udawatta Kele. Despite the forest reserve being completely surrounded by the Kandy town and its suburbs, there are many kinds of mammals, most of which are nocturnal. Mammals that can be seen the sanctuary are the endemic Pale-fronted Toque Macaque (Macaca sinica aurifrons), Mouse deer (Moschiola meminna), Porcupine (Hysterix indica), Indian Muntjac, Boar, Asian Palm Civet, Golden Palm Civet, Small Indian Civet, Ruddy Mongoose, Indian Giant Flying Squirrel, Greater Bandicoot Rat, Dusky Palm Squirrel, Indian Pangolin, Greater False Vampire Bat, Slender loris and Indian Flying-fox. Several kinds of reptiles also inhabit the forest: There are snakes such as the Common hump-nosed pit viper (Hypnale hypnale), Green vine snake (Ahaetulla nasuta), Green pit viper (Trimeresurus trigonocephalus), Banded kukri (Oligodon arnensis), Boie's rough-sided snake (Aspidura brachyorrhos) Sri Lanka Cat Snake (Boiga ceylonensis), Oriental Ratsnake (Ptyas mucosus) and Spectacled cobra (Naja naja). Lizards that can be seen include the Green Forest Lizard (Calotes calotes), Sri Lanka Kangaroo-lizard (Otocryptis wiegmanni) and the Whistling lizard (Calotes liolepis). There are also several species of skinks, geckos, frogs and toads. Some Sri Lanka wet zone butterflies are also present. The forest reserve has suffered from encroachment by squatters and land grabbing by surrounding land owners, but the forest ecosystem is now mainly threatened by invasive, introduced plant species that increasingly crowd away native plant and tree species and the animals and insects that live on them. These invasive species have no natural enemies such as diseases or insects and animals that feed on them and therefore grow and multiply much more rapidly than in their native habitats. Three introduced species pose the biggest threat to the natural biodiversity of the Udawatta Kele forest: The highly invasive Peru balsam tree Myroxylon balsamum from South America is the first. Dense stands of thousands of young trees can be seen along the roads in the eastern and northern side of the forest. The Pothos or Devil's Ivy, Epipremnum aureum, creeper from the Salomon Islands is the second major threat. In the Northwestern and Western part of the reserve, around the royal pond and near the presidential palace and Temple of the Tooth, the creepers completely cover several hectares of the forest floor. They also climb high up tree trunks, with their large leaves blocking the light for other species underneath. The creepers are gradually spreading further to the east and south. Some years ago they were even planted on road banks elsewhere in the forest. Mahagoney, Swietenia macrophylla, a timber tree from South America, is also quite invasive and disrupts the forest's diverse ecology. The Glow Vine, Saritaea magnifica, from Brazil is another invasive species, and covers several trees near the royal pond and near the Maitri cave. In some areas Aglaoneama communatum, Philippine Evergreen, is covering the forest floor and road banks. Severely degraded forest areas are situated between the Temple of the Tooth, the forest department office at the western entrance, and the slopes northeast of the royal pond. A few patches of unspoiled forest, with mostly native species of trees and shrubs, are remaining on the northern and eastern sides of the forest. There is also a patch of native forest on the southeastern side, near the forest department office at the southeastern entrance. The Forest Department has no management plan to maintain the biodiversity of the forest reserve and is not taking any action to curb the spread of and eradicate invasive species. Necessary control measures would be the uprooting of seedlings, collecting and destroying seeds, and removal of mother trees and creepers. In recent years the population of wild boar, of which there were none or very few in the forest until the early 2000s, has also increased dramatically due to the absence of predators. The boars' digging of the soil for seeking food and making mud-bathing places, causes soil erosion on hill sides and damage to the undergrowth.
